column55: This agreement is for a capitalization grant which provides funds for the recipient's Clean Water State Revolving Fund (CWSRF) program to provide low interest financing to recipients for costs associated with the planning, design, and construction of eligible water quality improvement and protection projects. The objectives are to establish and manage an effective comprehensive CWSRF program and to maintain a self-sustaining revolving fund so as to improve and protect water quality and public health.  This grant provides full federal funding in the amount of $113,653,000.  Pre-award costs have been approved back to July 1, 2020.
column56: 66.458: CAPITALIZATION GRANTS FOR CLEAN WATER STATE REVOLVING FUNDS
column90: Project will replace two aging facilities with a single headworks facility designed to: improve process performance (higher screenings and grit removal); minimize grit deposition in channels; handle a wide range of flow and load conditions (30 - 250 MGD); provide operational flexibility and reliability; contain odors within plant site; and provide an operation and maintenance (O&M) friendly facility. Project components include: new influent junction area; new fine screens and screening handlings; new grit removal and grit handling systems; and a two-stage odor control system.

column90: The Torresdale pumping station provides clean and vital drinking water to a large area of the City of Philadelphia. The current water pumps and associated mechanical systems are beyond the end of their useful service lives. The Torresdale Pump Station service area includes 263 sensitive facilities (i.e., schools, hospitals, home dialysis centers, dialysis centers, police, and fire stations), along with 221 critical facilities (i.e., schools, hospitals, home dialysis centers, and dialysis centers). Jefferson Torresdale Hospital is one of those facilities. If the pumps or mechanical systems within the pumping station fail large portions of the City could be without safe drinking water.The importance of replacing and maintaining infrastructure to provide clean drinking water to the City of Philadelphia is vital.

column55: This action approves an award in the amount of $26,865,000 to Georgia Environmental Finance Authority.  The purpose of this agreement is for a capitalization grant which provides funds for the recipient's Clean Water State Revolving Fund program.  The activities are to provide low interest financing to numerous subrecipients for costs associated with the planning, design, and construction of their eligible water quality improvement and protection projects.  The expected outcomes are to establish and manage an effective comprehensive Clean Water State Revolving Fund program and to maintain a self-sustaining revolving fund to improve and protect water quality and public health throughout the state of Georgia.  The direct beneficiaries of this award will be the citizens of the State of Georgia.

column90: This project involves the design and construction of bio-energy facilities at the existing site of the WSSC Piscataway WWTP in Prince Georgeâ  s County to receive sludge from the other WSSC wastewater treatment plants. The project will include a high-temperature thermal hydrolysis solids treatment process to precondition sludge prior to anaerobic digestion, anaerobic digestion facilities, and facilities to provide a dewatered Class A Biosolids. In addition, a combined heat and power facility will be constructed to capture the biogas from the digesters to be used for the production of steam and electrical power for the plant. Odor control, process water treatment, generators, and boilers are also included in the project. The anticipated project outcomes are: production of Class A Biosolids for beneficial uses, recovery of renewable energy from biomass and reduction in energy, chemical and sludge disposal costs.

column90: The New Castle Sanitation Authority Wastewater Treatment Plant has experienced hydraulic overloads during wet weather events, resulting in flows bypassing secondary treatment.  A Consent Order and Agreement was issued by the Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection on July 15, 2011, requiring the Authority to develop a plan for upgrades to be sure all flows conveyed to the plant are collected to receive both primary and secondary treatment. This phase (Phase II) is largely focused on the renovation and upgrades of the existing treatment process. This project phase includes the renovation of the primary clarifiers, construction of a new anoxic tank, renovation of the return activated sludge system, renovation of the final clarifiers, rehabilitation of the anaerobic digesters, and general site work.

column90: The wastewater plant originally constructed in 1967 experiences hydraulic overloads during wet weather events resulting in flows bypassing secondary treatment.  A Consent Order and Agreement was issued by the Department of Environmental Protection requiring the Authority to develop a plan for wastewater treatment plant upgrades to ensure all flows receive both primary and secondary treatment. This is the first phase of a multiple phase project to upgrade the Authority s wastewater treatment plant.  In this phase, the project includes the construction of a new headworks facility rated at 34.5 million gallons per day.  Included in the new headworks building are two new mechanical bar screens, two vortex grit chambers, yard piping, and other wet weather facilities.

column90: This project involves concrete rehabilitation and protective coating of the final clarifiers at the PVSC treatment facility. The concrete surfaces are significantly deteriorated and the concrete rehabilitation and application of a protective coating to cover over 200,000 square feet of walls, concrete columns and miscellaneous areas will allow this significant asset to be utilized well into the future. The work involves surface preparation, concrete lining and restoration of all surfaces and epoxy coating of pre-approved and demonstrated products. All expansion and construction joints will be replaced in all twelve (12) final clarifiers. Concrete repairs to walkways and stairs are also included in this project. Influent sluice gates will be installed in each of the twelve (12) final clarifiers as well.

This feed system will be co-located with the Pump Station No. 2 Ferric Chloride Feed System at the WRRF Chemical Facility, with interconnections between the two systems to provide process redundancy, back-up provisions and increase reliability.

The Strawberry Hill Road Sewer Expansion Project will install approximately 19,000 LF of gravity sewer, 9,300 LF of sewer force main and 1 new pump station. The project will provide a significant portion of the sewer infrastructure needed to address the wastewater needs of the Centerville River Watershed. The project is identified in the Townâ  s Wastewater Plan.
 
 The project involves the installation of sewer infrastructure to accommodate future sewer expansion identified in the Town's wastewater plan. The scope of work will include the installation of gravity sewer along Route 28, a sewer force main in Yarmouth Road will connect the future â  Old Yarmouth Roadâ   sewer expansion to the existing collection system and multiple force mains within Route 28.
 
 Barnstable has 27 wastewater pump stations and many of them have equipment that is well over its useful life and requires replacement to prevent anticipated major failures and impacts to public health and the environment. Pump station improvement projects over the next 20 years were identified in the Asset Management Plan. Several factors contributed to the recommendations for improvements in year 1 including the end of service life (useful life) of equipment, coastal resiliency, and energy improvements/electrical upgrades.
 
 This project includes upgrades and modifications to the existing WPCF. These improvements include the addition of two gravity belt thickening units as well as the replacement of other aged systems that have exceeded their useful life. The project seeks to replace or rehabilitate sludge pumps, dry polymer system, sludge holding tanks and blowers, odor control system, instrumentation systems, and other architectural and mechanical systems.

column90: The City of Mt. Sterling is requesting a Fund A loan in amount of $11,825,000. This is the construction portion of the Wastewater Capacity Upgrade Project that will bring the total cost of the project up to $12,500,000 after a contribution of $150,000 in local funds. The planning and design phase has been concluded with KIA loan A20-007 previously approved on July 1, 2019. This project will increase the capacity at Hinkston Creek WWTP from 3.0 MGD up to 6.0MGD and will increase the designed organic loadings from estimative 6000 lbs up to 10,000 lbs/day. The expansion will be constructed on adjacent site. Also, this project will increase capacity on the South Queen Street main sewer that is experiencing overflows. Statistical data indicates the facility is reaching its capacity, being at 79% hydraulically and 141 % capacity based on the design criteria concerning organic overloads. In addition this project will reduce inflow and infiltrations during substantial rainfall events to adequately maintain compliance.

column55: Clarkson University will identify and quantify pollutants in Great Lakes fish to support the Great Lakes Fish Monitoring and Surveillance Program (GLFMSP).  During the next five years of the GLFMSP, Clarkson University will continue to develop state-of-the-art capability to identify and quantify pollutants in fish at levels previously impossible to achieve, will expand the list of target chemicals to assess contaminant transfer through the food chain, and will augment existing analytical and outreach collaborations with other state and federal programs. This work will result in a clearer picture of the health of the Great Lakes ecosystem and how the ecosystem is being impacted by human activity.

column90: Harborcreek Township Sewer Authority collection system is hydraulically overloaded.  During wet weather events, raw sewage backs up and overflows at the 6 Mile Creek Pumping Station into 6 Mile Creek.  At full capacity, the 6 Mile Pump Station creates hydraulic issues within the Lake Road Interceptor causing raw sewage bypasses to 5 Mile Creek.  The project includes the reconfiguration of the Authority s collection system by installing 10,000 feet of various size sanitary sewer pipe, approximately 33 manholes, 2 meter vaults, upgrades to the 6 Mile Pump Station, and the construction of a 750,000 gallon surge tank at the 6 Mile Pump Station site.

column71: LOUISVILLE & JEFFERSON COUNTY METROPOLITAN SEWER DISTRICT
column90:
"The Louisville and Jefferson County Metropolitan Sanitation District (MSD) is requesting a Fund A loan in the amount of $8,270,000 for the Rosa Terrace, Sanders, Wathen and Sonne Pump Station project. This project will eliminate the Rosa Terrace and Sonne Avenue pump stations and replace the Wathen Lane and Sanders Lane pump stations. These are some of the most problematic pump stations in Jefferson County and all four are in low to moderate income areas. All of the pump stations are in the Dixie Highway area of Louisville adjacent to or just outside this significant commercial corridor. 
 
 The Rosa Terrace pump station will be eliminated with nearly 1,500 linear feet of eight-inch gravity sewer. Construction will occur in a residential/commercial area and will involve a railroad crossing. Some of the proposed sewer will be relatively deep which may require some more specialized construction techniques such as stacked trench-boxes or shoring, larger excavation equipment, and/or trench-less installation methods (jack-and-bore, micro-tunneling, etc.). Overall, the average depth of the sewer is approximately 17-feet. 
 
 Over 2,700 linear feet of eight-inch gravity sewer will be used to eliminate the Sonne Avenue Pump Station. In addition to having to cross a state road (Dixie Highway - 31W), portions of the sewer will be somewhat deep and in a residential area. Fortunately, there are numerous detour options and the impact to residents will be relatively minor. 
 
 To eliminate the Wathen Lane pump station rehabilitation project consists of a full replacement of the existing pump station. The existing pump station will be replaced with a new, modern station and will utilize the existing 6â   force main. As part of the layout of the proposed station, a dedicated entrance drive and concrete maintenance pad will be constructed to provide MSD staff with a safe and secure area to service the pump station in the future.
 
 The Sanders Lane pump station rehabilitation project consists of the replacement of approximately 450 linear feet of existing 4â   force main from the existing pump station. The new force main will follow the same general alignment of the existing. In addition to the force main replacement, there will be additional site improvements to the area immediately adjacent to the existing pump station. A dedicated entrance drive and concrete maintenance pad will be constructed to provide MSD staff with a safe and secure area to service the pump station in the future. This new concrete pad will also house a new emergency backup generator and the upgraded electrical components.
 
 Currently MSD serves over 220,000 residential and over 21,000 commercial and industrial customers."

column90:
The project will include the rehabilitation, renovation, and upgrade of the existing Heard County Filter Plant/Water Treatment Facility.  All construction will occur on the 11.5 acre site owned by the Heard County Water Authority at 200 Waterworks Road.  The Water Treatment Facility is a 3.0 MGD surface water plant which uses a â  package plantâ   system to treat water going to the distribution system.  The original plant was built in 1988 (1.0 MGD) and a parallel plant expansion was added in 1993 (2.0 MGD).  The purpose of this project is to repair, replace, and rehabilitate numerous components of the treatment plant that are outdated or have reached the end of their useful service life.  The upgrade of two 0.5 mgd filter units to 1.0 mgd filter units will increase the capacity of the plant to 4.0 MGD. These improvements would include, but are not limited to the following:
 â ¢ Building and structural repairs to the exterior wall panels, interior wall panels, roofing system, HVAC system, and steel structural support system
 â ¢ Building and structural improvements to include an expansion of storage and lab square footage, and rehab of existing administration area
 â ¢ Process equipment improvements to include structural repairs and corrosion protection of the existing steel tankage, replacement of the tube settlers, replacement of the media in the adsorption clarifier and the filters, and replacement of the flocculation equipment
 â ¢ Process equipment upgrades to include replacing two (2) existing 0.5 mgd Aquarius units with two (2) new 1.0 Trident units
 â ¢ Electrical and instrumentation improvements to include replacement of the controls, control panel, main service entrance wiring, and lighting system
 â ¢ On-site reservoir repair and replacement of the slide gate, foot valve, and airburst/compressor system for intake screen system
 â ¢ Replacement of multiple pump and motor systems including chemical feed pumps, influent pumps, reservoir pumps, and backwash pumps
 â ¢ Replacement of piping, valving, and metering systems throughout the plant
 â ¢ Replacement and upgrade of chemical feed systems including pumps, mixers, tanks, and appurtenances
 â ¢ The benefits of the project will include updating multiple plant components and increasing the service life of the building, filters, gallery piping, and process equipment.  The environmental impacts of the proposed project are negligible.

column90: Description: The project consists of upgrading the City s metering system from automatic meter reading (AMR) to advanced metering infrastructure (AMI) that allows two-way communication to better manage water billing, quickly detect meter accuracy problems, ensure that any leaks are quickly found and remedied, and increase water conservation and accountability in the system. Approximately 14,500 AMR meters throughout the system, or about 83 percent of total connections, will be upgraded to AMI meters by replacing the registers (electronic boards); three base stations/antenna will be installed at three elevated storage tanks (EST); and 13 repeaters will be installed at existing ESTs and existing and abandoned lift stations.

column90: Wastewater Pump Station (PS) Improvements: This project includes: replacement of existing wastewater pumps with new submersible pumps; replacement of the existing entry doors, roof, grating in the wet well, slide gates, fuel storage tank, MCC; upgrades to the ventilation system, oil furnace, unit heaters, and monorail system; and installation of new sewage grinder, VFDs, rock catcher, and magnetic flow meter. The Jones Ferry PS is considered the most critical PS in the City, because it pumps most of the flow that is conveyed to the WPCF in the Connecticut River Interceptor. The PS has several critical vulnerabilities, including one pump offline due to impeller failure, no means to isolate and bypass the PS, and aging infrastructure.

column90:
The proposed project plans to construct a new water treatment plant consisting of new ground waterwell(s), a ground storage tank, chlorination system, and treatment system for disinfection byproducts of sufficient size to supply North Ebarb and North Ebarb/Belmont service areas.  The new water treatment plant will be designed for a maximum daily water production of approximately 374,400 GPD.  It is anticipated that two wells may be needed due to low yield of the aquifer.  This will be determined from the test well data.
 
 The existing connection with Belmont will then be used as a backup supply in the event of a well failure.  The piping from Belmont is proposed to be routed to the new ground storage tank, so that when water from Belmont is used, it can be treated with both the proposed chlorination system and the proposed disinfection byproduct treatment system.  This will be required if Belmont is unable to achieve compliance with its own system.  Belmont has supplied water to both the North Ebarb and North Ebarb/Belmont service areas in the past and has maintained adequate pressure throughout its system in the process.

column90: This project involves upgrades to the existing raw water intake and water treatment plant to improve operational efficiency and overall treatment reliability.  The project will also provide needed redundancy in various treatment components and improve operator safety.  There will be replacement of raw water pump control valves, surge relief components, SCADA and electrical controls, and  the permanganate feed system.  There will also be improvement of the chemical feed system, modifications to sludge handling and storage facilities, installation of additional baffling in the clear wells, replacement of launders in the settling basins, replacement of backwash and surface wash valve actuators in the filter basin, replacement of flocculation basin paddles and drives, new filter basin controls, new influent and effluent controls, new bulk and day storage tanks, new SCADA and electrical controls, replacement of high service pumps, and miscellaneous site work.

column90: This project combines two projects, WX21137017 and WX21137052.  McKinney Water District is under an Agreed Order by the DOW for disinfection byproduct limits and the City of Stanford is having trouble providing water to the McKinney Water District.  This project considers the construction of a new water tank and replacing and enlarging at least a portion of the main asbestos cement water supply line.  Replacing the asbestos line will eliminate the biofilm layer built up by fiber inside the lines.  The system currently has two 100,000 gal standpipes that are over 50 years old.  Only a portion of the water is usable in the tanks due to pressure problems in the system.  This project will allow McKinney Water District to connect to the City of Danville system.

column31: UNIVERSITY OF NEW ORLEANS RESEARCH AND TECHNOLOGY FOUNDATION INC
column46: Nonprofit with 501C3 IRS Status (Other than an Institution of Higher Education)
column55: This agreement provides funding to the University of New Orleans Research and Technology Foundation (UNORTF) to support the Lake Pontchartrain Basin Restoration program which maintains, protects and restores the water quality of the Lake Pontchartrain Basin. UNORTF will oversee projects to monitor the lake's water quality and determine the health of the watershed, develop green infrastructure municipal education, educate basin residents on water protection and pollution prevention, conduct sewer system evaluations and surveys, and develop designs and studies to determine infrastructure upgrades to prevent or reduce pollution.
column56: 66.125: LAKE PONTCHARTRAIN BASIN RESTORATION PROGRAM (PRP)
column90:
Eight (8) needs in the Lake Pontchartrain Basin Comprehensive Management Plan (CMP) and three (3) needs in the
 Comprehensive Habitat Management Program (CHMP) are the focus of 10 tasks in this application.
 CMP Water Quality Needs:
 I - Provide a technical basis for water quality improvement actions through monitoring, needs assessment, and research
 (Tasks 1, 2, 3);
 II - Reduce adverse impacts of urban runoff on Basin water quality (Task 3);
 III - Eliminate sewage-related pollution impacts on Basin water quality (Task 3);
 IV - Reduce impacts of industrial and commercially generated pollution on Basin water quality (Task 3).
 LPBF s Water Quality Program will perform monitoring and research activities concerning water quality (Task 1, 2), and
 reduce pollution from commercial wastewater treatment plants (Task 3).
 ~~~~~~~~~~
 CHMP Needs (with page numbers for reference within the CHMP):
   Science to divert Mississippi River flow in new areas (including Lower Basin 99-105): Task 4;
   Optimize habitat benefits of the Caernarvon Diversion (102, 104); Task 4;
   Monitor the reestablishment of the baseline conditions due to Mississippi Gulf Outlet closure (90-102): Tasks 4, 5, 6.
 LPBF s Coast and Community Program will gather, analyze, and map data to share with subscribing researchers and
 fishers, including salinity and hypoxia data (Tasks 4, 5), as well as turbidity data at a Mississippi River diversion (Task 4),
 and using Geographic Information System (GIS) software to map the data (Task 6).
 ~~~~~~~~~~
 CMP Education/Public Participation Needs:
 II-Increase availability of appropriate educational materials to all residents in the Basin (Tasks 7, 8);
 III-Promote grassroots public participation in Basin cleanup (Tasks 7, 8); and
 IV-Promote environmental education and grassroots involvement of children in Basin cleanup (Tasks 7, 8).
 LPBF s public facilities on New Orleans  lakefront, the New Canal Lighthouse and its associated Lakefront Learning Lab
 provide a wide array of appropriate education materials. It has also been the hub of grassroots participation in Basin
 cleanup, as well as learning venues for tens of thousands of teachers and students since it opened in April 2013 (Task 7).
 Outreach (Task 8) activities advance our programming, online resources, and advocacy. This task is coordinated by the
 Executive Director and implemented by our outreach coordinator and social media consultant. Methods include our
 monthly e-newsletter and other strategic messaging through traditional and social media, with tracking activity and
 reporting results.
 ~~~~~~~~~~~~
 CMP Promoting Plan Implementation Need:
 I: Promote coordination among public and private entities whose actions affect or could affect the use, restoration,
 and/or preservation of the Pontchartrain Basin (Task 9).
 LPBF s Public Access efforts focus along the perimeter of the lake and adjacent waterways. LPBF staff functions as
 facilitator, liaison, and networker in fostering new public access opportunities along and near the lake. Staff also function
 as a watchdog regarding threats to continued access and/or degradation of accessible areas due to fly-dumping, etc.
 Leveraging partnerships for both the offensive and defensive activities described above is central to working with
 multiple parish officials, municipal leaders, business interests, and citizen advocates that help cultivate progress
 regarding use of the Basin.
 ~~~~~~~~~~
 Project Management and Reports (Task 10) encompasses all of the information presented above.

column55: Purpose: This agreement provides funding for the operation of the Washington Department of Ecology's air and water programs by consolidating and reducing the administrative burden into one grant while increasing the flexibility to reallocate resources between grants and programs to meet the highest environmental priorities in the state. Activities to be performed: The Performance Partnership Agreement includes joint Ecology and EPA activities related to air quality and water quality. Ecology is delegated by EPA to administer Clean Air Act and Clean Water Act activities addressed in the Agreement. Those activities are funded in part through EPA's consolidated Performance Partnership Grant. Expected Outcomes: This agreement funds statewide programs to: include outputs and outcomes associated with managing continuing environmental programs which include activities to protect and maintain air and water resources in Washington State. Intended Beneficiaries: Citizens of Washington State

column90:
"The City of Hazard (â  Cityâ  ) is requesting a Fund F loan in the amount of $1,637,500 for the Emergency Tank Replacement project. This project will replace the Liberty Street tank. This project will construct two 1,000,000 gallon ground storage tanks at the existing location. The existing will be demolished upon completion of the new tank. The project will include telemetry. Currently, the existing 2,000,000 million gallon tank feeds the entire Hazard system from the plant, when the tank has issues or needs maintenance, the system must be taken offline. By constructing two 1,000,000 million gallon tanks the City will be able to leave one tank in operation when issues arise or maintenance is necessary and therefore not have to take the system offline. The project will also include two VFD's at the plant. Governor Andy Beshear issued an emergency declaration due to the results of a tank inspection dated August 14, 2020 that deemed the tank unsafe and needed to be taken out of service.
 
 Currently the City of Hazard serves 9,000 residential and over 750 commercial customers. "

column56: 66.460: NONPOINT SOURCE IMPLEMENTATION GRANTS
column90: This proposal is the second segment of a locally planned multi-year (10-15 year) effort to implement best management practices (BMPs) in the Lewis and Clark Lake watershed, Lake Andes, Geddes, Academy and Platte Lake watersheds, impaired stretches of the Lower James River tributaries, and impaired reaches in the Vermillion watershed. column90:
"The City of Fleming-Neon is requesting a Fund F loan in the amount of $1,191,114 for the Fleming-Neon Waterline Improvement Project Phase 1. In order to combat high water loss due to aging water lines, the City of Fleming-Neon is planning to replace and modernize their water system. When the original system was created, GIS mapping was not available and data and information as to locations, line size and material have been lost over the years, making it almost impossible to detect or prevent breaks. 
 
 Phase 1 will replace approximately 10,200 feet of 8"" PVC and 4,400 feet of PVC waterlines from the water treatment plant on Shea Fork to the Neon city limits on Hwy 343 and Northeast along Hwy 343 to its intersection with Chopping Branch in the McRoberts area and any side roads. The project will address lines from the water treatment plant along Shea Fork to its end. The McRoberts area has been deemed the worst in the system. This phase will enhance the systems conversion to radio read meters by adding 149 new meters and provide flow-leak detectors in the system. Creek crossings will be directionally drilled to prevent biological disturbance. Trenchless/low-impact technology will be used when applicable.
 
 The City of Fleming- Neon currently serves over 1,000 residential customers in Letcher county."

column55: Funding this project will help to implement the Lake Champlain Management Plan in the Vermont portion of the Lake Champlain Basin. This grant contains projects that will help improve and/or evaluate the water quality and ecological health of the Lake Champlain Basin, including: long-term monitoring for water quality trend analyses; monitoring for cyanotoxins in lake water to help notify public health officials and water treatment operators if conditions pose a risk to public health; Vermont Lake Champlain Basin Program coordination; controlling the spread of invasive water chestnut; optimize and reduce wastewater treatment facilities discharge of phosphorus; developing assessment and planning for the forest phosphorus load allocation; implementation of non-municipal road and forest road improvements and pilot BMP implementation; continued support to increase capacity and resources to improve shoreland BMP's in Vermont's Lake Wise program; conservation of the Lamoille River Mudpuppy; targeted intervention in the Winooski Headwaters; restoration of Vermont's Deer Brook and continued work on restoration of Lake Carmi; continued support of priority wetland acquisitoin, restoration, and conservation to improve water quality; continued implementation of Vermont's enhanced agrilcultural practices; and stormwater planning, design, and construction of green stormwater infrastructure at public schools and Vermont state colleges in the Lake Champlain Basin.

column31: ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICES, NEW HAMPSHIRE DEPARTMENT OF
column55: This agreement will provide assistance to the New Hampshire Department of Environmental Services in its efforts to reduce diesel emissions and exposure throughout the State of New Hampshire. NHDES will initiate a sub-grant program applied broadly across various sectors in the state, employing a variety of diesel reduction strategies. Eligible diesel vehicles, engines, and equipment include verified emission control technologies such as exhaust controls, cleaner fuels, and engine upgrades, verified idle reduction technologies, verified aerodynamic technologies and low rolling resistance tires, certified engine replacements, and/or certified vehicle or equipment replacement. All projects will reduce emissions of diesel particulate matter and other pollutants such as nitrogen oxides, carbon monoxide, and hydrocarbons.
column56: 66.040: DIESEL EMISSIONS REDUCTION ACT (DERA) STATE GRANTS; 66.040: STATE CLEAN DIESEL GRANT PROGRAM
column90:
Under the Diesel Emission Reduction Act (DERA) the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) provides funding to states for projects that reduce harmful emissions produced by older diesel engines, including replacement of vehicles.  The new vehicles must meet more stringent emissions standards. Utilizing federal EPA funds, matched with funding from New Hampshireâ  s Volkswagen Environmental Mitigation Trust Fund, NHDES had $750,000 available for grants.  
 
 A request for proposal (RFP) was conducted from November 17, 2020 through January 19, 2021.  Nine entities applied for funding. Three proposals were approved for funding (see Attachment A for the scoring results), one of which was withdrawn. First Student requested partial funding to replace thirteen (13) engine model year 2006 to 2007 school buses. The 13 buses have an average age of just over 15 years, an average of 174,243 miles of operation and are listed as being in fair condition. They operate in a cold weather environment and are typically operated in a dual startup/shutdown mode (a morning run and an afternoon run) each operating day which increases wear and tear on the engine. School buses are also typically inactive for extended periods of time thus mileage is typically accrued over shorter operating times. The characteristics of the 13 school buses are shown in Figure 1.
  
 
 The DERA program has mandatory minimum cost share requirements for a vehicle replacement project of 75 percent. NHDES will provide a grant of the lesser of $289,468.00 or 25 percent of the total replacement cost (estimated $1,157,871.00) to First Student, Inc. for the replacement of 13 school buses.

column90: Arsenic treatment facility to treat water from CRUUA's Border Region Wells.  All the wells have arsenic concentrations above the EPAs max contaminant level of 10 parts/billion. A Stipulated Final Order and Settlement Agreement  was issued by the NMED that requires CRRUA to bring the Border Region Wells into compliance with the arsenic MCL by 12/31/2022. The arsenic treatment facility will have a treatment capacity of 800 gpm (1.15 MGD) and will be located adjacent to the Border Region Tank and Booster Station.  The tank is the entry point to the distribution system and the sampling compliance point for the system.

column90: Placitas obtains it's water through a 4-in asbestos cement transmission line along HWY 26. It is comprised of 4-in asbestos cement and 2-in steel lines. The small diameter lines inhibit the ability to provide adequate flows and reduces the ability to flush lines through hydrants. Operators report large amounts of corrosion causing leaks and breaks. Service lines are a mix of copper and PVC, making repairs more complicated which increases operation and maintenance costs. Current pressures are kept low to minimize breaks in the older service lines and corroded steel distribution lines. This project will provide residents with a safe and reliable source of potable water.

column55: Cornell University will collect zooplankton, mysis, benthos and chlorophyll data across the Great Lakes from 2017 to 2022, analyze long-term data for trends and make it available to water quality and fisheries managers. Additional research will include new sampling strategies including video surveys, barcoding and remote sensing, invasive species impacts, and the impact of decreased lower trophic level production on fisheries.
column56: 66.469: GREAT LAKES PROGRAM

column71: RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK, THE
column81: Non-Profit Organization,Educational Institution,State Controlled Institution of Higher Learning
column90: Buffalo State will be responsible for all aspects of benthic and special studies associated with benthic sampling. Burlakova will be responsible for the grant management at Buffalo State College and contribute to semi-annual reports. They will keep lead PI Rudstam informed of progress on deliverables, and discuss and get prior approval for any significant deviations from the proposed budget. PI Burlakova will see that all these relationships are managed to produce timely and efficient products, spending and reporting. Together with their research scientist and senior taxonomist, they will collect samples onboard of EPA R/V Lake Guardian during summer benthic sampling cruises and CSMI surveys, and perform samples sorting and identification. Karatayev, Burlakova and Mehler will be responsible for analyses and interpretation of data, reports and manuscript writing, and will supervise the graduate student. Burlakova and Karatayev will lead the special study on the effect of Dreissena on benthic invertebrates, and Mehler and Karatayev will be responsible for new methods for Dreissena sampling (video analysis) that has a potential to reveal the significance of fluctuations in dreissenid populations. In addition, the benthic team will participate in the comparison of results produced by Cooperative Science and Monitoring Initiative and Long-term Monitoring surveys to assess how the monitoring design can contribute to the goal of each lake-specific CSMI.

 piping

 Electrical building, BNR Load Center, to house the BNR electrical equipment for the mixers, pumps,

 Fermentate pumps, two WAS pumps,

 includes

column55: This action approves an award in the amount of $559,258 to the Iowa Department of Natural Resources to support their efforts with improving water quality in the Gulf of Mexico by demonstrating innovative approaches to increasing long-term adoption of soil health practices and restoration efforts to improve floodplains. This project will create mentoring opportunities to increase the adoption of conservation and demonstrate new tactics to be applied across Iowa.
column56: 66.475: GULF OF MEXICO PROGRAM
column90: The Beaver Creek Watershed Management Authority (WMA) will work with the recipient to demonstrate innovative approaches to increasing long-term adoption of soil health practices, scaling up the installation of edge of field practices, and restoration efforts to improve floodplains. These efforts take a local approach to tackling Iowa's nutrient reduction strategy in a diverse watershed that affects Iowa's most populated metropolitan area. Diverse mentoring opportunities will be created between farmers, conservationists and agricultural business to increase the adoption of conservation measures and demonstrate new tactics that will positively impact water quality in Iowa streams and ultimately improve water quality in the Gulf of Mexico.  A team of soil health and edge of field experts will facilitate these efforts resulting in a one-stop shop for edge of field practices in the Beaver Creek watershed, restoring 100 acres in the Beaver Creek floodplain, and enrolling 15 landowners in a cover crop/no-till system.

column67: AGRICULTURE AND LAND STEWARDSHIP, IOWA DEPARTMENT OF
column90: Dry Run Creek watershed encompasses 15,177 acres comprised of about 30 miles of stream. The watershed drains from the rural and agricultural areas of Black Hawk County into the industrial, commercial and residential areas of Cedar Falls before it outlets into the Cedar River.  Dry Run Creek is on Iowa's Section 303(d) impaired waters list for low quantity and quality of aquatic life as well as high levels of bacteria. As designated in the Watershed Management Plan, goals for the project include reducing the connected impervious surfaces located throughout the watershed through infiltration-based practices.  The Black Hawk Soil and Water Conservation District has lined up 9,000 s.f. of bioswales; 11,000 s.f. of permeable pavement, a streambank stabilization project, and a wetland project.  There are also plans to work within the community on the residential scale to implement rain gardens, permeable paver driveways, soil quality restoration, and native prairie establishments.  In working with rural landowners and producers, conservation practices including grassed waterways, cover crops, and conservation tillage will be implemented to help reduce soil erosion and sediment delivery to the stream.  Together these practices will help Dry Run Creek improve the quality of water for the aquatic creatures that live within it as well as the residents that call Cedar Falls home.

column46: Public/State Controlled Institution of Higher Education
column55: The Great Lakes Coastal Wetland Monitoring Program will implement a long-term Great Lakes-wide coastal wetland monitoring program using a scientifically validated sampling design and protocols for condition assessment of wetland plant, invertebrate, fish, amphibian, and bird communities and water quality. Field teams led by Central Michigan University will sample approximately 1000 coastal wetlands during the five-year award period (2021-2025).
column56: 66.469: GREAT LAKES PROGRAM
column67: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA
column81: Non-Profit Organization,1862 Land Grant College,Educational Institution
column90:
Over the past ten years 2011-2020, a team of scientists across the Great Lakes region has coordinated and completed a comprehensive survey of Great Lakes coastal wetlands. This proposed sampling program aims to re-sample wetlands for another 5-year period (2021-2025) using the same methods and protocols. 
 As in the previous two 5-year rounds of this sampling program, NRRI lead V. Brady will help manage the overall sampling program for Central Michigan University and be the program's quality assurance manager. She will also coordinate and oversee work by an NRRI database programmer and a GIS specialist to provide GIS and database support for the whole project. She will also serve as the western sampling team lead and coordinate the wetland sampling efforts in western Lake Michigan and Lake Superior for fish and macroinvertebrates (Dumke); aquatic vegetation (with UWS collaborator N. Danz); birds and anurans (Bracey), and water quality (Filstrup).

column67: AGRICULTURE AND LAND STEWARDSHIP, IOWA DEPARTMENT OF
column90: Rathbun Lake is the primary source of water for the Regional Water Association (RRWA) which is one of the largest rural water associations in the U.S. and the largest system in Iowa.  The RRWA provides 8 million gallons of water daily to nearly 80,000 people for residential, business and agricultural use in 18 counties and 51 communities.  In addition, the 11,000 acre lake offers recreational activities for one million visitors annually and is the site of Honey Creek Resort State Park.  The Rathbun Lake watershed includes slightly more than 354,000 acres and encompasses six counties.  The overall goal of the Protect Rathbun Lake Project is to reduce sediment and phosphorus delivery to Rathbun Lake and the lake's tributaries through implementation of the Protect Rathbun Lake Interim Watershed Management Plan.  Project activities will assist landowners in applying best management practices (BMPs) to help achieve this goal.  The proposed activities in this phase will result in the installation of BMPs treating 1,640 acres.  At least 820 acres will be priority land with the remaining acres considered associate priority land.  The BMPS will reduce the annual delivery of sediment and phosphorus to Rathbun Lake by an estimated 3,775 tons and 5,085 pounds respectively.  In addition to the 54 targeted sub-watersheds in which this project is currently active, activities will also be expanded into the Lower Jackson Creek targeted sub-watershed encompassing 7,024 acres delivering an estimated 6,360 tones of sediment and 8,550 pounds of phosphorus each year to Rathbun Lake. Thirty-five landowners own and/or operate farms with priority land in the sub-watershed and at least 17 of these are highly likely to install BMPs.

 Develop and promote a cost-share program to implement best management practices, conduct a monitoring program to show general trends in water quality, and conduct an education and outreach program designed to bring about behavioral changes and encourage BMP implementation that will lead to reduced nonpoint source pollution in the watershed.

 Implement best management practices, conduct a monitoring program following the guidelines of a QAPP, and conduct an education and outreach program by holding workshops/field days, steering committee meetings, distributing flyers/brochures/ and newsletters. Conduct watershed tours, develop and utilize a 15'X20' walkable watershed map for public events.

column90:
The Sullivan County SWCD will produce a WMP for the headwaters of the Maria Creek watershed, HUC 0512011118 and No Business Creek Watershed, HUC 0512011117.
 
 Objectives
 
 The Sullivan County SWCD plans to improve water quality in the Maria & No Business Creek Watersheds by accomplishing four main objectives over the course of four years. 1) Develop a Watershed Management Plan 2) Develop and Implement an approved Cost-Share Program 3) Establish a water quality monitoring/assessment program 4) Increase Public Awareness and Stewardship Through Outreach and Education.
 
 Methods
  The WMP will serve as a compiled analysis of all baseline data, newly collected monitoring data, land use information, resource concerns, and stakeholder input. It will clearly outline all information necessary for the determination of critical areas within the watershed. Once critical areas are defined, they will begin to formulate long-term goals in order to systematically address water quality concerns through the implementation of BMPs and conservation efforts.
 Overview:
 The Grantee shall develop and promote a cost-share program to implement best management practices (BMPs) such as conservation tillage, exclusion fencing, hay/pasture land improvement and others that address the water quality concerns outlined in the Maria-No Business Creek Watershed Management Plan.
 
 Objectives:
 Develop and promote a cost-share program to implement best management practices, conduct a monitoring program to show general trends in water quality, and conduct an education and outreach program designed to bring about behavioral changes and encourage BMP implementation that will lead to reduced nonpoint source pollution in the watershed.  
 
 Methods:
 Implement best management practices, conduct a monitoring program following the guidelines of a QAPP, and conduct an education and outreach program by holding workshops/field days, steering committee meetings, distributing flyers/brochures and newsletters. Conducting community events, public meetings, press releases and Hoosier Riverwatch Training events.

column56: 66.468: CAPITALIZATION GRANTS FOR DRINKING WATER STATE REVOLVING FUNDS
column90:
This project proposes to replace approximately 28,000 LF of existing 2", 4", 6", and 8" problematic and 8" undersized waterlines in Edmonton's distribution system. The line replacements will include the following: 6,300 LF of 8" and 6" PVC on Highway 80 North; 2,200 LF of 6" PVC on Greensburg Street; 3,400 LF of 6" PVC on West Stockton & Miller Streets; 3,500 LF of 6" PVC on Highway 640; 1,500 LF of 8" PVC on Highway 90 and 11,600 LF of 4" PVC on  Lonestar Ridge Road. The existing control / pressure reducing station on Highway 3234 will be also replaced. 
 
 The project will also extend approximately 15,100 LF of new 3" waterlines to create two (2) new loops to improve water quality and eliminate dead end waterlines. The new line construction will include: 7,100 LF of 3" PVC on Peckerwood Ridge Road and 8,000 LF of 3" PVC on Roy Grider Road.
 
 In addition to waterline replacements and extensions, this project will rehab, construct, and decommission water tanks and pump stations to improve water quality, pressure, and efficiency in the distribution system. One new water tank will be constructed, four (4) existing water tanks will be rehabilitated or modified, and one existing water tank will be decommissioned. Two existing pump stations will be replaced with upgraded pump stations, one pump station will be modified, and one pump station will be eliminated. SCADA will be upgraded or modified on all new, rehabilitated, or modified tanks and pump stations.
 
 The existing 200,000 gallon Edmonton tank and 100,000 gallon Gascon tank will be completely rehabilitated including miscellaneous structural repairs, new interior and exterior coatings, control valve vaults and piping modification. The existing turnover issues at the 100,000 Gallon Harvey Estes tank and 100,000 Gallon Hickory Ridge tank will be also addressed through piping modifications. The piping and control valve arraignments at all four (4) existing tanks will be modified such that the tanks will fill near the top and drain from the bottom of the bowl. This will greatly improve the turnover and reduce the production of disinfection byproducts. A new Summer Shade 250,000 gallon elevated storage tank will replace the existing 100,000 gallon structure to address inadequate storage and alleviate pressure issues in portions of the distribution system. 
 
 The existing Highway 90 booster pump station that fills the Summer Shade tank will be replaced with a new station, increasing the capacity from 120 GPM to approximately 225 GPM.  The existing Harvey Estes pump station, that fills the Gason and Hickory Ridge tanks will be also be replaced new station, increasing the capacity from 250 GPM to approximately 300 GPM. The existing Harvey Estes pump station will remain and be modified only for use in supplying fire service to an industrial user.

Federal funds of $6,464,000 are contingent upon availability. This award supports Delaware in meeting its nutrient and sediment allocations, with the overall goal of achieving the restoration and protection of the Chesapeake Bay watershed and its living resources. This will be accomplished by implementing Delaware's Watershed Implementation Plans (WIPs) that detail a mix of best management practices (BMPs), wastewater treatment technology upgrades, and other activities necessary to restore and protect the Chesapeake Bay. Beneficiaries of this project include residents of the Chesapeake Bay watershed, human health, and environment. The recipient intends to subaward funds to support local implementation of best management practices aimed at improving water quality.
column56: 66.466: CHESAPEAKE BAY PROGRAM
column90: The Chesapeake Bay Implementation Grant will provide funding for cover crop implementation in the most effective basins of Sussex County, Delaware.

column4: Q: Excluded from tracking (uses non-emergency/non-disaster designated appropriations)
column46: Public/State Controlled Institution of Higher Education
column55: The Great Lakes Coastal Wetland Monitoring Program will implement a long-term Great Lakes-wide coastal wetland monitoring program using a scientifically validated sampling design and protocols for condition assessment of wetland plant, invertebrate, fish, amphibian, and bird communities and water quality. Field teams led by Central Michigan University will sample approximately 1000 coastal wetlands during the five-year award period (2021-2025).
column56: 66.469: GREAT LAKES PROGRAM
column90:
Our research team, consisting of collaborators form the universities of Windsor (Jan Ciborowski, Lead PI) and Wisconsin-River Falls (Joseph Gathman CoPI), Canadian Wildlife Service (Great Lakes) of Environment and Climate Change Canada (Greg Grabas, coPI) and Bird Studies Canada (Doug Tozer, coPI) will be responsible for sampling coastal wetland sites on the eastern side of the Great Lakes basin, particularly those on the Canadian shorelines of lakes Ontario, Erie, St. Clair and Huron and the Detroit, St. Clair and St. Marys rivers. Lake Erie sites in Pennsylvania, Ohio and Michigan may also be samples by our group. 
 Our research team monitoring approximately 40 Great Lakes coastal wetlands per year between 2021 and 2025 as allocated annually according to the detailed study design of the project. The detailed methodology will follow the protocols recommended by the Great Lakes Coastal Wetland Monitoring Consortium (Burton et al. 2007) as amended and described in detail and implements in the Quality Assurance Program Plan (QAPP) implemented for the current 5-year GLRI0funded project in which we are currently participating, Coastal Wetland Monitoring: Continued Implementation by the GLCWC (â  CWM-2â  , Uzarski et al. 2015; Brady et al. 2019). 
 Each year (February-April), we will review the candidate list of proposed sampling sites to confirm that they meet sampling criteria (suitable size, connection to a Great Lake, habitat type, and accessibility). Field crews will also be trained, updated in revised protocols and tested for proficiency at this time. Birds and amphibians at each wetland will be assessed on 3 occasions in spring or early summer by the Bird Studies Canada team using Marsh Monitoring Program protocols (Uzarski et al. 2015). Sampling and monitoring for water quality, vegetation, aquatic invertebrates and fishes will be conducted at each wetland during single visits between June 1 and September 30 each year. Water quality will be assessed by using field meters and by collecting samples for determination of nutrient concentrations and routine parameters at an analytical laboratory. Composition of the plant community will be assessed by documenting the identify and areal coverage of species in quadrants assigned among various transects. Fishes will be live-trapped in Fyke nets set overnight, enumerated, identified to species, measures and released. Aquatic invertebrates will be collected using D-frame dip nets. Groups of 150 individuals will be hand-picked form samples collected in each of several vegetation zones, preserved in ethanol and later identified in the laboratory. Voucher specimens of all collections will be kept in reference collections and/or provided to regulating agencies as required by terms of reference of collection permits. Accuracy of data will be quality checked internally and by exchanging specimens with companion teams to cross-validate identifications. All QAâ  d data will then be entered into the Coastal Wetland Monitoring database. All research findings will be communicated in semi-annual reports submitted to EPA, in annual meetings of the PIs and at academic and other meetings that provide opportunities to describe our progress and interim results.

The Grantee shall develop and promote a cost-share program to implement best management practices (BMPs) such as conservation tillage, exclusion fencing, hay/pasture land improvement and others that address the water quality concerns outlined in the Deer Creek-Sugar Creek River Watershed Management Plan.
 
 Objectives:
 Develop and promote a cost-share program to implement best management practices, conduct a monitoring program to show general trends in water quality, and conduct an education and outreach program designed to bring about behavioral changes and encourage BMP implementation that will lead to reduced nonpoint source pollution in the watershed.  
 
 Methods:
 Implement best management practices, conduct a monitoring program following the guidelines of a QAPP, and conduct an education and outreach program by holding workshops/field days, steering committee meetings, develop and distribute cost-share announcement mailings. Attend partner and regional decision-maker meetings. Manage a website and social media updates. Host demonstration days/field days/workshop and conduct a booth at local county fairs.

column90:
The Wabash River Enhancement Corporation will address water quality problems and improve education and outreach in three 10-digit watersheds :Wea Creek, Burnett Creek-Wabash River, and Kickapoo Creek-Wabash River. These watersheds were initially chosen by WREC and their project partners because they include high levels of urban and agricultural activity; contain stakeholders that are interested in water quality improvement and possess documented E.coli, nutrient, sediment and biotic community impairments. The watersheds ,collectively referred to as the Region of the Great Bend of the Wabash River (RGBWR) watershed, drain 478 square miles covering 70% of Tippecanoe County and extending into Benton, Warren, Fountain, White and Montgomery counties. More than 90% of Tippecanoe County residents feel a connection to the Wabash River with nearly 70% indicating that they are willing to make a change to positively impact water quality in the Wabash River.  Identify and implement projects in the Burnett Creek-Wabash River, Wea Creek and Kickapoo-Wabash River Critical Area subwatersheds, which will result in measurable changes in water quality. Continue targeted and watershed-wide education and outreach efforts to increase awareness about water quality in the Wabash River and engagement of individuals that will implement BMPs. Identify long-term funding mechanisms to achieve project sustainability.
 Methods:Develop and promote a cost-share program targeted at the Burnett Creek-Wabash River, Wea Creek and Kickapoo-Wabash River Critical Area sub-watersheds

 Objectives:
 Develop and promote a cost-share program to implement best management practices with a goal to reduce 64,103 tons of Nitrogen, 30,300 lbs of Phosphorus, and 88.5 tons of Sediment. The Ouabache Land Conservancy will also conduct an education and outreach program designed to bring about behavioral changes and encourage BMP implementation that will lead to reduced nonpoint source pollution in the watershed.  
 
 Methods:
 Implement best management practices, and conduct an education and outreach program by holding workshops/field days, steering committee meetings, distributing flyers/brochures/fact sheets and newsletters. Conducting Hoosier Riverwatch Trainings, administer social indicators survey to measure community awareness of the Otter Creek Watershed water quality issues and improvement.

column90:
Well Site 9 was developed in the mid 1980â  s. The current facilities are over 35 years old and are deteriorating. Well 9 was never equipped to meet its permit limits, and the well hole is not straight, resulting in maintenance issues. The well has seen a decrease in production due to sanding and is susceptible to power outages. Replacement of Well 9 will require drilling a new well within 150 feet of the existing well in order to be considered a replacement well under the existing permit. The City would like this well to be re-drilled and equipped to fulfill the 2,419 AFY of water permitted for this well. The new well will be drilled in accordance with the hydrogeologistâ  s recommendations. 
 Furthermore, power availability will be analyzed and extended as necessary to mitigate power outages. Water from Well 9 is currently treated with a Hungerford and Terry coagulation-filtration arsenic treatment system constructed in October 2006. Water is also chlorinated with ferric and PH adjustment prior to entering the water distribution system. The requirements for treatment at Site 9 will be determined upon well production and water quality testing of the re- drilled (new) well. It is anticipated that arsenic treatment will be required based on other wells in the Cityâ  s water system. The existing arsenic treatment has a maximum capacity of 0.95-MGD; therefore, the system will likely 
 need to be expanded or replaced to meet the new well capacity. (See attached Planning Document with CPB Approval Letter). The City 
 recently purchased several acres of adjacent property, which has been environmentally cleared (See attached EID) for this project and is 
 already in design to construct a 3MG steel holding tank on site. The construction of this tank will begin in the Fall of 2020 and will be funded 
 entirely with City funds. The DWSRF Funds will be used to construct a new (replacement) well on site, install new pump and a new variable 
 frequency drive (VFD) motor system, install adequate arsenic treatment facilities, and build a new well house and security fencing. The estimated construction costs for this project is approximately $15M.

column55: Perfomance Partnership Grant funds are used by the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment (CDPHE) to perform delegated program activities, perform quality assurance activities, and maintain regional and national databases associated with environmental programs. These include Clean Air, Clean Water, Hazardous Waste Management, Safe Drinking Water, Toxics Management and Abatement, and Pollution Prevention. The Performance Partnership Agreement PPA serves as the definitive workplan for the Performance Partnership Grant (PPG). As such, the PPA/PPG in tandem provides the State greater flexibility to address its highest environmental priorities, improve environmental performance, achieve administrative savings and strengthen the partnership between the State and the Environmental Protection Agency.

column55: This agreement provides funding to the State of Indiana Department of Environmental Management to carry out its program to maintain, protect, and improve the water quality of its rivers, lakes, streams, groundwater, and other waterbodies. The environmental benefits of this program include preventing degradation of unimpaired waterbodies and reducing the number of impaired waterbodies in the state. Activities include collecting fish tissue data from waters throughout the state of Indiana to support multiple water quality management objectives, purchase monitoring equipment to deploy at three regional monitoring network sites, and fund a contractor with the ability to combine several different data sets for Indiana lakes into a single master spreadsheet file to use in developing an attribute-rich, high-resolution Indiana Reach Index (a geospatial data layer at 1:24,000 scale) for lakes.
column56: 66.419: WATER POLLUTION CONTROL STATE, INTERSTATE, AND TRIBAL PROGRAM SUPPORT
column67: OHIO RIVER VALLEY WATER SANITATION COMMISSION
column90:
The Grantee shall collect and analyze fish tissue samples for total PCBs and methylmercury as well as other contaminant constituents of interest or concern and will report these analytical results to IDEM for consideration in its Clean Water Act water quality assessment 
 and listing processes to support development of the Indiana Integrated Water Monitoring and Assessment Report. To further support this objective, a secondary goal of this project is to explore PFAS in these fish tissue samples collected. The Grantee shall maintain a database of existing fish tissue data collected from the project area. The Grantee shall collect and prepare additional fish composites necessary to achieve the sample goal of four different species each in trophic levels 3 and 4. In total, the Grantee shall provide ten (10) composite samples per pool comprising four (4) composite samples and one (1) replicate for each of two (2) trophic levels in accordance with the timeline shown in Table 1. Grantee shall have all fish tissue samples analyzed at its contract analytical services laboratory for PFAS, total PCBs, methylmercury, total mercury, selenium, lead, and pesticides (scaleless fishes only).

column55: The Southwest Environmental Finance Center, University of New Mexico will address technical, managerial, and financial (TMF) capacity through training and technical assistance. The project will build the internal TMF capacity of small water utilities by using a variety of delivery methods to provide access for all types of water system personnel, including those with limited access to technology. The awardee will blend traditional approaches with new and innovative ones to enable systems to improve compliance, increase resiliency, manage assets at the lowest life-cycle cost, communicate with decision makers and ratepayers, have appropriately trained staff, and assess their financial health and affordability.
column56: 66.424: SURVEYS, STUDIES, INVESTIGATIONS, DEMONSTRATIONS, AND TRAINING GRANTS - SECTION 1442 OF THE SAFE DRINKING WATER ACT
column68: OFFICE OF RESEARCH AND SPONSORED PROGRAMS
column81: U.S. Local Government,U.S. State Government,Educational Institution,State Controlled Institution of Higher Learning
column90:
1.Consultation with State Regulatory and Funding Agencies - In coordination with the Southwest Environmental Finance Center (SWEFC) and other members of Environmental Finance Center Network (EFCN) on this project, Wichita State University's Environmental Finance Center (WSU EFC) will meet, virtually or in-person, with regulatory and funding agencies in each of the Region 7 states (Kansas, Nebraska, Iowa and Missouri), and other states as needed.
 2.Develop and Deliver Trainings - The WSU EFC will develop, coordinate and conduct in-person and/or virtual trainings on the following topic areas as requested by regulatory and funding agencies in each state. It is anticipated that WSU will provide 20 total trainings: one in each of the four (4) EPA Region 7 states (Kansas, Nebraska, Iowa and Missouri) and sixteen (16) trainings in other locations outside Region 7 based on topic requests, audience needs and availability. Trainings may be virtual or in-person events. 
 In order to provide quality and relevant trainings with the most up-to-date resources, information and tools, WSU EFC staff will also participate in trainings, conferences, workshops and meetings to build additional internal knowledge and network capacity to ensure trainings, webinars, biogs, technical assistance, resource development, etc. meet the high standards the water utilities in our nation expect and deserve.
 3.Technical Assistance -The WSU EFC will provide technical assistance to twenty (20) systems. Technical assistance may be on-site, by phone, virtually or via e-mail to water systems in the locations and topic areas listed in Task #2. The length of the assistance to each individual drinking water system may vary depending on the needs of the system and the requests of the state or territory, but there is a general target of 10-15 hours of assistance provided per system.
 4.Develop and Deliver Durable Resources -Through engagement with state agency stakeholders, WSU EFC, SW EFC and EFCN will identify educational topic and format needs (virtual, onÂ demand, social media and durable resources). WSU EFC will develop, and participate in the development of, virtual education events (webinars, biogs, podcasts, recorded e-learning, etc.) and durable/ongoing resources (checklists, videos, white papers, social media communications, etc.) on topics listed in Task #2. Resources that are developed will be hosted on EFCN or SW EFC websites. 
 5.Tribal and Diversity, Equity and Inclusion Focus -WSU EFC will make every effort to reach out to tribal utilities in each state where we provide trainings. WSU EFC staff work regularly with tribal utilities. WSU EFC will also review outreach and marketing plans for trainings and resources to ensure that the trainings and resources are equitably accessible to diverse and inclusive audiences.
 6.Coordinating Meetings -The WSU EFC will participate in coordinating meetings related to the Small Systems project. Most meetings will be virtual. However there will be at least one inÂ person meeting to kick-off this project. The Director, Tonya Bronleewe, and the Project Lead, currently, Nicholas Willis, will attend this meeting.
 7.Project Reporting -This project requires monthly verbal progress reports with the SW EFC as the lead applicant with the EPA Project Officer and quarterly written progress reports. WSU will provide information for progress reporting in an electronic EFCN database for each of these types of progress reports. In addition, WSU will participate in project conference calls as required by the SW EFC to ensure that the project activities are on track. If any in-kind services are provided as part of the project, the estimated cost of these services will be reported as part of the project match. Other types of documentation may be required as requested by the SW EFC in order to ensure that the project reporting methodology is providing adequate information to the EPA, the project team and other stakeholders.

Task 1: Manage Project's External and Internal Communications 
 SU-EFC will implement and manage a communications plan for the project, for project and partner coordination and for marketing strategies. All outreach and communication activities will be coordinated by and through SU-EFC. SU-EFC will coordinate material content development, prepare marketing materials and develop and distribute an electronic newsletter for the duration of the project SU-EFC will prepare mailings (as needed) for specific trainings and distribute them, and will prepare and print training booklets for program activities (as needed). SU-EFC will be the technical host for all webinars and will provide content for the project website. 
 Task 2: Manage Project Logistics 
 SU-EFC will create, implement and manage a logistics plan for the delivery of all program deliverables. This will include publicity, venue and training team coordination. SU-EFC will also be the lead subcontractor to manage all training event logistics and will manage much of the work of other subcontractors. 
 Task 3: Facilitate communication and consultation with State and Territory Regulatory and Funding Agencies 
 Maintain communications between the University of New Mexico EFC with state regulatory and funding agencies as well as with Regional EPA contacts. SU-EFC will then help prioritize the types of activities (trainings or assistance) needed in each state.
 Task 4: Support and Attend Region 2 trainings; and Provide Workforce Development and Resiliency trainings

column56: 66.123: PUGET SOUND ACTION AGENDA:  TECHNICAL INVESTIGATIONS AND IMPLEMENTATION AS; 66.123: PUGET SOUND ACTION AGENDA: TECHNICAL INVESTIGATIONS AND IMPLEMENTATION ASSISTANCE PROGRAM
column90:
This project is part of the Habitat Strategic Initiative FY20 NEP funding allocation (NTA 2018-0873).
 
 Snohomish Conservation District will collaborate with partners to develop the Index of Floodplain Health, an integrated approach for monitoring the effectiveness of multi-benefit projects. This grant will support the Sustainable Lands Strategy efforts in Snohomish and Stillaguamish River watersheds by identifying and prioritizing multi-benefit recovery projects that 1) recover floodplain functions and improve salmon habitat 2) reduce flood damages and protect floodplain community health and safety and 3) support sustainable and vibrant farming. The Index of Floodplain Health is expected to include a weighted decision matrix for assisting stakeholders with prioritizing projects and policy initiatives, a suite of indicators/metrics and targets to describe floodplain health, and an implementation process or strategy for measuring and a roadmap for tracking progress.

column55: The Southwest Environmental Finance Center, University of New Mexico will address technical, managerial, and financial (TMF) capacity through training and technical assistance. The project will build the internal TMF capacity of small water utilities by using a variety of delivery methods to provide access for all types of water system personnel, including those with limited access to technology. column56: 66.424: SURVEYS, STUDIES, INVESTIGATIONS, DEMONSTRATIONS, AND TRAINING GRANTS - SECTION 1442 OF THE SAFE DRINKING WATER ACT
column67: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH CAROLINA AT CHAPEL HILL
column81: Non-Profit Organization,Educational Institution,State Controlled Institution of Higher Learning
column90:
Public drinking water systems protect human health, support emergency response, and facilitate economic development. When systems falter, technical, financial and/or managerial deficiencies often exist, which are intensified for small systems due to a lack of economies of scale, inadequate staffing, retention and training, insufficient managerial capacity, insufficient revenues, lack of asset management and planning to manage capital costs, difficulty navigating external funding, and lack of understanding and meeting regulatory requirements.  
 To assist these small water systems, the Environmental Finance Center Network proposes to increase the technical, managerial and financial capacity of small water systems by delivering comprehensive training and technical assistance to help system operators, managers, and governing body members understand their roles and responsibilities and regulations, understand expenses, develop sound revenue generation measures, improve efficiency, manage assets at the lowest life-cycle cost, communicate with decision makers and ratepayers, and have appropriately-trained staff to ensure compliance.
 
 The broader teamâ  s proposal outputs include in-person workshops, webinars to either a national or state audience, technical assistance efforts, rates dashboards, and blog posts. Expected outcomes include systems with greater technical, financial and managerial capacity to provide safe drinking water and ensure compliance.  
 UNC Deliverables:
 â ¢15 trainings  
 â ¢8 webinars 
 â ¢30 technical assistances  
 â ¢5 blog posts 
 â ¢8 updated funding matrices for R4 2 rates dashboards

column90: Black Hawk Lake is a natural lake in Sac County, Iowa with a drainage area of 13,256 acres and is currently on the 303(d) impaired waters list for algae and turbidity. The focus of the project is to work with partners, residents, landowners and farm operators to reduce nutrient and sediment loss.  The watershed has a goal of addressing the excess sediment and phosphorus load that has been identified as the primary cause of water quality problems in the lake.  TMDL findings indicate that a 78% reduction in phosphorus inputs is needed to achieve water quality success.  This sub-award will place emphasis on load reductions from rural and urban inputs. For agricultural inputs, the targeted load reduction is 315 tons per year of sediment and 552 pounds per year of phosphorus.  For urban inputs, the target load reduction is 135 pounds of suspended solids and a 40% reduction in phosphorus inputs.

column55: Great Lakes Long-term Biological Monitoring Program 2017-2022 Cornell University will collect zooplankton, mysis, benthos and chlorophyll data across the Great Lakes from 2017 to 2022, analyze long-term data for trends and make it available to water quality and fisheries managers. Additional research will include new sampling strategies including video surveys, barcoding and remote sensing, invasive species impacts, and the impact of decreased lower trophic level production on fisheries. This supplemental amendment obligates additional federal funding in the amount of $302,131. These funds support the workplan activities in accordance with Consolidated appropriations Act, 2016, Public Law No: 114-113 guidelines.
column56: 66.469: GREAT LAKES PROGRAM

column81: Non-Profit Organization,Educational Institution,State Controlled Institution of Higher Learning
column90: Buffalo State will be responsible for all aspects of benthic and special studies associated with benthic sampling. Burlakova will be responsible for the grant management at Buffalo State College and contribute to semi-annual reports. They will keep lead PI Rudstam informed of progress on deliverables, and discuss and get prior approval for any significant deviations from the proposed budget. PI Burlakova will see that all these relationships are managed to produce timely and efficient products, spending and reporting. Together with their research scientist and senior taxonomist, they will collect samples onboard of EPA R/V Lake Guardian during summer benthic sampling cruises and CSMI surveys, and perform samples sorting and identification. Karatayev, Burlakova and Mehler will be responsible for analyses and interpretation of data, reports and manuscript writing, and will supervise the graduate student. Burlakova and Karatayev will lead the special study on the effect of Dreissena on benthic invertebrates, and Mehler and Karatayev will be responsible for new methods for Dreissena sampling (video analysis) that has a potential to reveal the significance of fluctuations in dreissenid populations. In addition, the benthic team will participate in the comparison of results produced by Cooperative Science and Monitoring Initiative and Long-term Monitoring surveys to assess how the monitoring design can contribute to the goal of each lake-specific CSMI.

column90: This project will provide an expanded toolbox for evaluating subsurface conditions, determining stormwater infiltration feasibility, and estimating infiltration capacity. The expanded toolbox will address shortcomings with existing test methods, provide less expensive methods that are easier to conduct, and address important factors such as perching on impervious layers and groundwater mounding. The expected end result is to provide more cost-effective infiltration design recommendations.

column90: Neonicotinoid insecticides are the most commonly used insecticides in the world today. These insecticides are routinely found in Washington State surface waters, often as mixtures and at low concentrations. In this study, the RECIPIENT will determine the potential effects of the three most commonly detected neonicotinoids in our surface water, imidacloprid, thiamethoxam and clothianidin, on aquatic invertebrate communities.

column55: This agreement provides assistance to the Green Bay Metropolitan Sewerage District to implement its project to support the Great Lakes Restoration Initiative (GLRI) to protect and restore the chemical, physical, and biological integrity of the Great Lakes Basin ecosystem.  Specifically, the recipient will implement a cost-share program for installation of permanent vegetative buffers on 35 acres of headwater streams as part of an adaptive water quality trading approach. The project will illustrate the performance of innovative and permanent management practices and demonstrate its capacity to accomplish sediment and nutrient reductions goals in the Lower Green Bay Fox River, resulting in reduced phosphorus loading of approximately 2,000 lbs. annually.

column90:
The Grantee shall develop and promote a cost-share program to implement best management practices (BMPs) such as conservation tillage, exclusion fencing, hay/pasture land improvement and others that address the water quality concerns outlined in the Big Pine Creek River Watershed WMP.
 
 Objectives
 Develop and promote a cost-share program to implement best management practices, conduct a monitoring program to show general trends in water quality, and conduct an education and outreach program designed to bring about behavioral changes and encourage BMP implementation that will lead to reduced nonpoint source pollution in the watershed.  
 
 Methods
 Implement best management practices, conduct a monitoring program following the guidelines of a QAPP, and conduct an education and outreach program by holding workshops, steering committee meetings, distributing flyers.

Project consists of the construction of 7,400 LF of 8-inch water main to replace existing undersized and asbestos-cement waterlines along Tutt Str. and Bomar Heights.  The project will also include 5,250 LF of 6-inch water main in associated cross streets in this area. column90: The Mobile Board of Water and Sewer Commissioners (MAWSS) (CS010281-19) proposes implementation of Mobileâ  s CWSRF Master Plan Phase I (Years 2019-2023) to include: replacement of dewatering system and construction of new chlorine building at Williams WWTP; addition to Eslava Creek Severe Weather Attenuation Tank (SWAT) storage and conveyance; installation of Williams WWTP to Eslava Creek parallel sewer main; slip-lining of Pre-stressed Concrete Cylinder Pipe (PCCP) Halls Mill Connection to South Broad Street and from South Broad Street to Williams WWTP; refurbishment of existing Three-Mile Creek SWAT Tank; replacement of Headworks, renovations to Maintenance Building, replacement of Digester Dome, and additional access driveway at Smith WWTP; and Lift Station SCADA Programming. Proposed improvements will insure continued compliance with existing regulations and demands and provide increased efficiency and dependability to the Boardâ  s overall wastewater collection and treatment system.
