column55: These funds are for the operation of the Texas Commission on Environmental Qualitys (TCEQ) continuing environmental programs while giving it greater flexibility to address its highest environmental priorities, improve environmental  performance, achieve administrative savings and strengthen the partnership between TCEQ and EPA.  This agreement funds statewide programs to assist the TCEQ in administering the States base water quality program that aims to prevent, reduce, and eliminate water pollution through standard-setting, monitoring, permitting and enforcement activities and to assist in administering the States environmental management programs which monitors, abates, and controls hazardous, solid waste, air pollution and pesticides. The work includes outputs and outcomes associated with managing continuing environmental programs which include activities to protect and maintain air, water, land, pollution prevention and chemical safety. Direct beneficiaries include the residents of Texas.

column4: Q: Excluded from tracking (uses non-emergency/non-disaster designated appropriations)
column55: This agreement provides funding to the State of Texas to carry out its program to maintain, protect, and improve the water quality of its rivers, lakes, streams, groundwater, and other waterbodies. The environmental benefits of this program include preventing degradation of unimpaired waterbodies and reducing the number of impaired waterbodies in the state. Activities include supporting work for a comprehensive survey of the nation's wetlands. The National Wetlands Condition Assessment is a statistical survey of wetlands of the U.S. This survey is designed to: 1. Produce a national report that describes the status of water quality of nation's wetlands, 2. evaluate change in the status of the nation's wetlands since the initial phase in 2010, 3. help states implement wetland monitoring and assessment programs to guide policy development and project decision-making, and 4. advance the science of wetland monitoring and assessment.

Restore America's Estuaries (RAE) will manage a cooperative agreement that will solicit, award and administer competitive subaward grants between $75,000 and $250,000. The overarching goal of this project is to reduce threats to the ecological and economic well-being of coastal and estuarine areas by advancing the implementation of NEP Comprehensive Conservation and Management Plans (CCMPs) and/or state or local-approved watershed management plans within the geographic areas defined as NEP Coastal Watersheds.

column55: The Environmental Finance Center Network, the Government Finance Officers Association, the National Association of Development Organizations, and the Rural Community Assistance Corporation will provide training and technical assistance to small drinking water systems in the areas of financial and managerial capacity. The team will help systems understand their expenses, develop sound revenue generation measures, improve energy and water efficiency, manage assets at the lowest life-cycle cost, communicate with decision makers and customers, and have appropriately trained staff to maintain compliance. Services will focus on either a single finance or management topic (e.g., asset management) or package several topics into a theme (e.g., natural disaster resilience).

column55: This agreement provides funding for the operation of massachusetts Department of Environmental Protection’s continuing environmental programs while giving it greater flexibility to address its highest environmental priorities, improve environmental performance, achieve administrative savings and strengthen the partnership between massachusetts Department of Environmental Protection and the Environmental Protection Agency. Through this multi media performance partnership grant, the massachusetts Department of Environmental Protection will administer environmental programs for air, water, and waste/toxics throughout the state of massachusetts and direct resources as appropriate to address environmental and public health concerns.  This agreement also contains activities that complement existing environmental programs. Specifically, the Massachusetts Department of Environmental Protection will use the multipurpose funding to install and operate an ambient air monitoring station in the Fore River Basin area of Weymouth, Massachusetts.  The work includes outputs and outcomes associated with managing continuing environmental programs which include activities to protect and maintain air, water, and land by monitoring, using pollution prevention, assessment, and relevant cleanup techniques, permitting, enforcement, standard setting, and/or inspections for the various multi media programs.  The project works to enhance the effectiveness of Hood Canal watershed protection and restoration actions, evaluate the impacts of policies and projects on priority landscapes, and inform comprehensive solutions to complex community and environmental challenges. The LAP Tool pilot phase (NTA 2016-0397, funded by NEP) was completed at the end of March 2020, and was very successful in developing the LAP Tool's analytical approach, methodology, and building engagement and interest from local partners. The next phase of the LAP Tool would benefit many aspects of watershed planning, looking across silos to apply its prioritization capabilities to restoration and protection actions, including salmon recovery and land use protections. column55: This action awards $3,707,318 ($9,400 of which represent EPA in-kind funding).   Federal funds in the amount of $6,088,604 are contingent upon availability.   The purpose of this grant is to aid Maryland Department of Natural Resources (MD DNR) with implementation of the Chesapeake Bay Implementation Grant (CBIG) program. Activities funded under this award are aimed at implementing the management mechanisms established under the 2014 Chesapeake Bay Watershed Agreement, with particular emphasis on state programs for control and abatement of nonpoint source nutrient and sediment pollution. Beneficiaries of this program include human health and the environment, as well as residents in the Chesapeake Bay watershed. MD DNR intends to sub-award funds to local partners to fund projects related to community resilience and education, as well as implementation of agricultural best management practices and storm-water projects.

column90: The Stormwater Management and Community Engagement in the Lower Gwynns Falls Watershed objective will support Blue Water Baltimore in working with West Baltimore neighborhoods to plant and maintain 250 urban trees and identify stormwater projects.  Blue Water Baltimore (BWB) is one of the key technical assistance providers working to restore the watersheds in Baltimore City and Baltimore County.  The fundamental principle woven into all of BWBâ  s work is close collaboration with the community, which ensures that all efforts are equitable and ultimately results in the most durable outcomes because buy-in is in place.  This program will address community-scale stormwater and climate resilience needs while also helping to advance recommendations made in Marylandâ  s Phase III Watershed Implementation Plan.  This work also aligns with 2014 Chesapeake Bay Watershed Agreement goals and will uphold the Chesapeake Executive Councilâ  s commitment to diversity, equity, inclusion and justice.

This project will facilitate the adoption of on-farm nutrient-loss reduction strategies among farmers in the mississippi and Atchafalaya River Basins to achieve water quality goals.
column56: 66.475: GULF OF MEXICO PROGRAM
column68: DIVISION OF AGRICULTURE OF THE UNIVERSITY OF ARKANSAS
column81: U.S. State Government,1862 Land Grant College,Educational Institution,State Controlled Institution of Higher Learning
column90: Objective 1: We will build leadership capacity among farmers by (1a) identifying core competencies for their success as leaders, (1b) developing trainings that equip them with core competencies, and (1c) recruiting new farmer leaders in project watersheds.    Mike Daniels, Project Leader for Arkansas will serve as advisor for 1a and 1b while the new Project Coordinator for Arkansas will perform 1c.  Key tasks include:  â ¢Hire Project Coordinator  â ¢Mike Daniels and Coordinator will participate in meetings for 1a and 1b  â ¢Mike Daniels and Coordinator will provide critical review of core competencies and training materials  â ¢Project Coordinator will work with Discovery Farmer and three satellite farmers to become watershed leaders.  â ¢Project Leader will pilot training   Objective 2: We will improve the effectiveness of communications and outreach strategies used by farmer leaders (primarily) and conservation professionals (secondarily) to reach and influence more farmers to adopt conservation practices by creating a replicable campaign model that combines relationship-driven and data-driven approaches  While the new Sustainable Use of Poultry Litter in Row crop Discovery Farm is being funded from a different source (i.e. edge-of-field runoff monitoring in four fields and sample analysis), this proposed project will leverage that work to provide data on the effect of poultry litter and conservation practices on water quality of runoff.  The grant will further extend our efforts on this farm to include the monitoring of selected soil health parameters including soil chemical properties such as the routine Arkansas soil test analysis used for fertilizer and lime recommendations, organic matter, Haney Soil Health Test, and the Arkansas N-ST*R Soil Test for the mineralizable portion of Nitrogen in soil.  Soil physical properties include bulk density, aggregate stability, particle size analysis and infiltration using Meterâ ¢ automated infiltrometers and biological properties such as nematodes.     This data will be incorporated into farmer-led educational programs to support the use of the replicable campaign model in four Counties in Arkansas where poultry litter is readily available for use on row crops.  The Discovery Farmer and Satellite farmers will use the data collected on their farm to educate and persuade other farmers to adopt conservation practices associated with the use of poultry litter as fertilizer for crops.  Objective 3: We will evaluate (3a) social and (3b) environmental outcomes of our interventions and farmer practices in project watersheds.   Environmental outcomes documented in Arkansas will include water quality data for nutrients and total suspended solids from runoff at the edge-of-field for four fields for various practices utilizing poultry litter.  Soil health parameters listed above will be monitored on the Discovery Farm and the three satellite farms to determine if poultry litter when used properly can improve soil health.  The program coordinator will organize and conduct educational meetings and track the number of direct contacts, the number of acres where practices are adopted and the number of farmers influenced by the campaign model described above.

column55: The Ohio EPA Division of Surface Water will partner with local governments, local soil and water conservation districts (SWCDs), and the Ohio State University (OSU) to implement six non-point source pollution projects in the Maumee Watershed. These projects will reduce nutrient runoff into Lake Erie by implementing structural, agricultural conservation practices focused on preventing gully erosion and increasing the treatment and retention of runoff water. Altogether, these projects will result in an annual load reduction of approximately 6103 pounds of nitrogen, 1307 pounds of phosphorus, and 1078 tons of sediment and capture approximately 1 million gallons of stormwater runoff annually. Additionally, up to 14 Nonpoint Source Implementation Strategy (NPS-IS) plans will be developed for nearby watersheds.

column55: This agreement provides funding to Washington State Recreation and Conservation Office to enhance its technical capabilities and capacity to use and support the Exchange Network (EN). EN is an Internet and standards-based, secure information network, that facilitates the electronic collection, exchange, and integration of the full range of data that informs the business of environmental protection. The EN and this project, will ultimately streamline and modernize environmental management processes and data collection and reporting. This in turn will improve the efficiency, effectiveness, and ease of exchanging environmental information within organizations, with the regulated community, the public or between co-regulators which is key to successful environmental program management. Specifically, the project's work seeks to design and develop a new data exchange for hatchery high-level indicators (HLI). Additional project outputs include organizing HCAX Project Governance; confirming
column56: 66.608: ENVIRONMENTAL INFORMATION EXCHANGE NETWORK GRANT PROGRAM AND RELATED ASSISTANCE
column90: This  proposal supports PSMFC- StreamNet in this HCAX project through the EPA- Exchange Network FY 2020.  It will inform environmental decisions and reporting requirements related to both ESA-listed and non-listed salmon and steelhead, as well as species that rely on these fish as prey resources, such as Southern Resident Orca whales (2019 recommendations: https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/OrcaTaskForce_FinalReportandRecommendations_11.07.19.pdf ).  This grant supports fisheries biologists of the WDFW, Colville Tribes, StreamNet and PNAMP staff, and staff from Idaho Department of Fish and Game (IDFG) and Oregon Department of Fisheries and Wildlife (ODFW), to achieve the following major outputs or outcomes in collaboration with their data management, developer, and programmer experts: 1) advance sharing of standardized metrics and HLIs for hatchery salmon and steelhead in a well-defined, transparent manner across the Pacific Northwest within EPAs Region 10; 2)  improve consistency in the information communicated with the public, and that used for environmental reporting required by and for regional decision-making in multiple forums; 3) support and contribute to the reporting for states, tribes, tribal consortia, federal agencies (BPA, US Fish and Wildlife Service, and National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA)-Fisheries) and other partners: NPCC, Oregon Watershed Enhancement Board, and GSRO (see Table 2, Attachment- Formal Partners)

column67: AGRICULTURE AND LAND STEWARDSHIP, IOWA DEPARTMENT OF
column90: The Iowa Great Lakes are an interconnected chain of natural lakes with a watershed of roughly 87,000 acres in NW Iowa (76%) and SW Minnesota. The Iowa Great Lakes are a major recreational destination for Iowa residents and visitors from adjacent states. Agricultural runoff containing sediment, fertilizers, pesticides, herbicides and feedlot waste negatively affect water quality in the lakes.  Urbanization also contributes to pollution via storm water runoff, and there a number of private sewage disposal systems in the watershed area that are improperly installed or maintained. In 2010 the Iowa Great Lakes Watershed Management Plan was developed for the purpose of removing and preventing impairments in the watershed, guided by Total Maximum Daily Load (TMDL) documents developed for Lower and Upper Gar Lakes as well as Milford Creek which is the outlet for all of the Iowa Great Lakes chain.  This plan has been updated in 2013 and 2018 to reclassify subwatershed priority and other changes as needed.  Primary targeted watershed areas for this round of funding include East Okoboji Beach, Reeds Run, and Highway 71 subwatersheds. Other subwatersheds will implement BMPs through the project as opportunities arise, especially in conjunction with the Source Water Protection special project funded by EQIP. This subaward is an amendment to add additional funding to the FFATA subaward reported in June 2020.

column90: Easter Lake is a 178 acre man-made reservoir within the city limits of Des Moines, Iowa constructed in 1967 on the site of the last operating coal mine in Polk County and is one of the largest active restoration projects in the state.  A neighborhood organization promoted the use of the area as a park rather that a proposed landfill.  The lake is largely within the borers of Easter Lake Park managed by the Polk County Conservation Board with three other city parks within the 6,380 acre watershed.  The lake suffers from poor water clarity, algal blooms, high sedimentation rates, low oxygen concentrations, and a poor fishery.  Since construction, the water volume has decreased by nearly 30% as a result of sediment being deposited in the lake.  Watershed modeling has identified high sediment and phosphorus loads originating from predominately urban areas of the watershed and the Yeader Creek drainage area.  Phase 2 projects and programs are aimed at reducing external pollutant delivery to the lake through cost-share and financial incentives for watershed BMPs and two major stream stabilization projects. Watershed BMPs will focus on rainscaping practices such as rain gardens, bioswales, pervious pavement and more.  Decreasing the transport of eroded soil is critical to restoring Easter Lake and the watershed to a healthy, functioning system.  The goal of Phase 2 is a 25% reduction of sediment and 20% reduction of phosphorus loading.  This sub-award is for Year 9 of the watershed action plan targeting the reduction of sedimentation and phosphorus loading by 5%.

The Cityâ  s wastewater collection system currently includes twenty-three (23) wastewater pump stations that flow into two (2) of Volusia Countyâ  s water reclamation facilities. column90:
The overall goal of Iowa State University's Conservation Learning Group is to be the collaborative voice of the major conservation stakeholders in Iowa to help advance the efforts of both the Nonpoint Source Management Plan (NPSMP) and the Iowa Nutrient Strategy (NRS).  In 2011, the DNR commissioned four stakeholder listening sessions as part of the revision process of the NPSMP.  The purpose was to give Iowa citizens a voice in updating the plan.  The resulting report, 'Water Quality Matters to Us All', highlighted the challenges and collaborative effort needed to both understand water quality and work towards improvement of Iowa's waters.  A decade later, it is important to revisit the themes of that influential report and Iowa State University plans to conduct a statewide evaluation to highlight the new and changing voices in conservation and water quality in Iowa.
 Deliverables include:  survey of Iowans across many demographics; six listening sessions; evaluate nine watersheds with stream signs and two without (outreach effectiveness monitoring); video campus interviews at regents universities on watersheds and water quality; 20-25 video interviews of newer voices in conservations and environmental leadership in Iowa; production of the final 'Water Quality Matters to Us All: A Vision for the Future' report; all other federal- and state-required reporting outputs.  The DNR will utilize this information to fulfil parts of several portions of the Iowa Nonpont Source Management Plan.

column90:
This project proposes to replace approximately 28,000 LF of existing 2", 4", 6", and 8" problematic and 8" undersized waterlines in Edmonton's distribution system. The line replacements will include the following: 6,300 LF of 8" and 6" PVC on Highway 80 North; 2,200 LF of 6" PVC on Greensburg Street; 3,400 LF of 6" PVC on West Stockton & Miller Streets; 3,500 LF of 6" PVC on Highway 640; 1,500 LF of 8" PVC on Highway 90 and 11,600 LF of 4" PVC on  Lonestar Ridge Road. The existing control / pressure reducing station on Highway 3234 will be also replaced. 
 
 The project will also extend approximately 15,100 LF of new 3" waterlines to create two (2) new loops to improve water quality and eliminate dead end waterlines. The new line construction will include: 7,100 LF of 3" PVC on Peckerwood Ridge Road and 8,000 LF of 3" PVC on Roy Grider Road.
 
 In addition to waterline replacements and extensions, this project will rehab, construct, and decommission water tanks and pump stations to improve water quality, pressure, and efficiency in the distribution system. One new water tank will be constructed, four (4) existing water tanks will be rehabilitated or modified, and one existing water tank will be decommissioned. Two existing pump stations will be replaced with upgraded pump stations, one pump station will be modified, and one pump station will be eliminated. SCADA will be upgraded or modified on all new, rehabilitated, or modified tanks and pump stations.
 
 The existing 200,000 gallon Edmonton tank and 100,000 gallon Gascon tank will be completely rehabilitated including miscellaneous structural repairs, new interior and exterior coatings, control valve vaults and piping modification. The existing turnover issues at the 100,000 Gallon Harvey Estes tank and 100,000 Gallon Hickory Ridge tank will be also addressed through piping modifications. The piping and control valve arraignments at all four (4) existing tanks will be modified such that the tanks will fill near the top and drain from the bottom of the bowl. This will greatly improve the turnover and reduce the production of disinfection byproducts. A new Summer Shade 250,000 gallon elevated storage tank will replace the existing 100,000 gallon structure to address inadequate storage and alleviate pressure issues in portions of the distribution system. 
 
 The existing Highway 90 booster pump station that fills the Summer Shade tank will be replaced with a new station, increasing the capacity from 120 GPM to approximately 225 GPM.  The existing Harvey Estes pump station, that fills the Gason and Hickory Ridge tanks will be also be replaced new station, increasing the capacity from 250 GPM to approximately 300 GPM. The existing Harvey Estes pump station will remain and be modified only for use in supplying fire service to an industrial user.

column56: 66.442: ASSISTANCE FOR SMALL AND DISADVANTAGED COMMUNITIES DRINKING WATER GRANT PROGRAM (SDWA 1459A)
column90:
Grant monies totaling $420,000 with a required (45%) state match of $343,636, which will be met with state appropriations from the Drinking Water and Groundwater Trust Fund, have been made available to the New Hampshire Department of Environmental Services (NHDES) through the Water Infrastructure Improvement for the Nation (WIIN) Act, Assistance for Small and Disadvantaged Communities Drinking Water Grant administered by the United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA).  NHDES proposes to use the funds to assist a select list of small and disadvantaged water systems to provide funding assistance for improvements to their drinking water systems necessary to comply with the Safe Drinking Water Act (SDWA), address water supply capacity issues or respond to a drinking water contaminant. 
 
 The Drinking Water and Groundwater Bureau (DWGB) intends to use the grant funds to develop and implement a small/disadvantaged grant program for the neediest water systems in the State. Initially, two community water systems are identified as meeting eligibility requirements for the subawards. Additional eligible recipients will be identified as funding allows.  
 
 In conjunction with a Drinking Water State Revolving Fund (DWSRF) loan Marlborough Estates will use the grant funds for water system improvements including source replacement, and pump house and water storage upgrades. The three existing bedrock wells have all significantly declined in their capacity to provide an adequate supply to the community.  This project will improve water quantity and quality issues as well as improve resiliency.
 
 The South Weare Water Association will use the grant funds for water system improvements including developing a new water supply well with associated infrastructure, controls, and water treatment needs. Additional improvements include water main replacement, meter installation, pump house upgrades and water storage improvements. The water system lacks the capacity to meet even average daily water demands, the community endures frequent and extended water outages, and water is not reliably available. This project will improve water quantity and quality issues as well as improve resiliency and reliability.
 
 In the event that grant funds no longer become available, General funds will not be requested to support this program. This agreement has been approved by the Attorney Generalâ  s Office as to form, substance and execution.  
 
 We respectfully request your approval of this item.

column28: 00L2: WATER QUALITY RESEARCH ADN SUPPORT GRANTS
column46: Public/State Controlled Institution of Higher Education
column55: Communities across the United States are struggling with aging or inadequate wastewater infrastructure. When systems falter, technical, managerial, and financial (TMF) deficiencies often exist. These challenges are intensified for small wastewater systems due to a lack of economies of scale, insufficient managerial capacity, and the difficulties of complying with regulatory requirements. To assist small wastewater systems and onsite/decentralized systems, the Environmental Finance Center Network (EFCN) Team (SW EFC, UMD EFC, UNC EFC, MTU EFC, WSU EFC, CSU EFC, and MSU WRRI) will help communities address technical, managerial, and financial (TMF) capacity through training and technical assistance.  They will blend traditional approaches with new and innovative ones to enable systems to improve compliance, increase resiliency, manage assets at the lowest life-cycle cost, communicate with and ratepayers.
column56: 66.436: SURVEYS, STUDIES, INVESTIGATIONS, DEMONSTRATIONS, AND TRAINING GRANTS AND COOPERATIVE AGREEMENTS - SECTION 104(B)(3) OF THE CLEAN WATER ACT
column81: Private University or College,Other Not For Profit Organization,Educational Institution
column90:
Syracuse University will contribute to the efforts of the full project team by preparing, organizing, and delivering training and technical assistance on wastewater asset management practices. 
 
 These training and technical assistance modules will be delivered via a mixture of face-to-face remote learning modes. Face-to-face training modules will feature hands-on learning activities on asset management practices. Face-to-face training will be the preferred mode for communities with the CNY region and for multi-state regional technical assistance events under normal circumstances. These training sessions will feature classroom training, workshops, and site visits. Remote learning modes will be used when conditions due to COVID-19 or budgetary concerns make face-to-face training impossible or infeasible. Remote learning modes will feature video conferences, online courses, and webcasts. Syracuse team will take advantage of Syracuse University Environmental Finance Centerâ  s network in identifying communities of highest need and in tailoring training material to address any specific needs of these communities. Training modules will also be customized for needs of different stakeholders (e.g., managers, operators, maintenance personnel). Specifically, the SU-EFC will provide the following:
 â ¢3 In-Person Trainings
 â ¢2 Virtual Trainings
 â ¢3 Technical Assistances (Tas)
 â ¢3 Blog posts
 â ¢3 Podcasts
 â ¢1 Educational Videos
 â ¢1 Peer-to-peer Learning Sessions
 â ¢Travel to Round 9 Retreat
 Additionally, the SU-EFC will manage all projects logistics, internal and external communications and marketing, and will work with the Southwest EFC to engage with state agency contacts and EPA Regional contact.
 
 All activities will be undertaken in close collaboration with the full project team. The anticipated output of Syracuse teamâ  s effort is an increased number of stakeholders receiving training on asset management of small publicly-owned wastewater systems and onsite/decentralized wastewater systems. The anticipated outcome of Syracuse teamâ  s efforts is wider adoption of asset management programs within stakeholders who manage onsite/decentralized wastewater systems and small public-owned wastewater systems.

column67: OHIO RIVER VALLEY WATER SANITATION COMMISSION
column90: The Ohio River Valley Sanitation Commission (ORSANCO) will continue to operate two previously installed continuous monitors along the Indiana portion of the Ohio River. The two monitors will record temperature, pH, conductivity, dissolved oxygen (DO), turbidity, chlorophyll a, and phycocyanin. In addition, grab samples will be collected and analyzed twice per month at both locations (total 48 samples). Analysis will include nitrate-nitrite, Total Kjeldahl Nitrogen, Total Phosphorus, Soluble Reactive Phosphorus (SRP), Total Suspended Solids (TSS), Dissolved Organic Carbon (DOC), chlorophyll a, algal taxonomy, and algal toxins. The Grantee shall calibrate each continuous monitor twice per month (total 48 calibrations). ORSANCO also maintains a website to receive continuous monitoring data. The data will also analyzed and reported on for causes of algal blooms.

column28: 0004: CATEGORICAL GRANT:  STATE AND LOCAL AIR QUALITY MANAGEMENT
column55: With this funding the Utah Department of Environmental Quality will conduct ambient air monitoring and a health risk assessment of Ethylene Oxide emissions from major commercial sterilizers in Utah. Recent epidemiological studies showed that Ethylene Oxide is a more potent carcinogen than previously documented, resulting in an update to the inhalation risk estimate for Ethylene Oxide. This resulted in the identification of Ethylene Oxide as a potential health concern in several areas across the United States, including in the state of Utah. Modeling results from the 2014 National Air Toxics Assessment indicate an increased potential cancer risk from Ethylene Oxide for several census tracks across the United States due to emissions from 26 facilities, including two in Utah. The first is a medical sterilization facility located in close proximity of the Salt Lake City International Airport. The other is a medical device manufacturing plant located in Sandy, Utah who uses Ethylene Oxide to sterilize the medical equipment it manufactures. To characterize ambient emission of Ethylene Oxide from the facilities and assess their health impact on surrounding communities, the Utah Department of Environmental Quality is proposing to conduct ambient monitoring in the vicinity of the two facilities. 24-hour canister measurements will be collected at multiple sampling sites, located near and at different distances from the sterilization facilities. Measured ambient data will then be used in a health risk assessment analysis to identify cancer and non-cancer risks associated with the exposure to Ethylene Oxide from these facilities.

column81: For Profit Organization,Woman Owned Small Business,Woman Owned Business
column90:
As part of the Chesapeake Bay Trustâ  s multi-year EPA funded project to develop a comprehensive Conowingo Watershed Implementation Plan (CWIP) Financing Strategy and associated implementation plan, Throwe Environmental proposes to work in partnership with the University of Maryland Center for Global Sustainability (UMD) to continue the development, design, and implementation of an innovative financing system.  The results of this financing system are expected to provide greater financing scale and efficiency in support of water quality and pollution reductions defined in the CWIP.  The first two years of the CWIP Financing Strategy project were devoted to developing the framework for a financing system that ultimately led to a key recommendation for an interstate financing authority to be established utilizing an existing institution, the Susquehanna River Basin Commission (SRBC).  Working directly with the SRBC and key finance advisors will be the primary focus of Throwe Environmentalâ  s proposed scope of work.  
 
 As part of this project, Throwe Environmental anticipates interaction with leaders within the Chesapeake Bay states, the Bay Program Office, the SRBC, finance experts, and UMD that will help to assess the viability of a â  proof of conceptâ   project for establishing an interstate financing institution.  The role of Throwe Environmental will be to identify the processes, resources, and structure necessary to launch a sustainable financing system for the Conowingo restoration effort.

column90:
Lower Eel River Watershed
 Overview
 Clay County Soil and Water Conservation District (SWCD) will review and revise the current cost-share program. 
 
 Objectives
 The SWCD will promote the implementation of best management practices (BMPs) in the critical areas that are identified in the Lower Eel River Watershed Management Plan (WMP). 
 
 Methods
 The Clay County SWCD Staff and/or volunteers will conduct an unfunded water quality monitoring program in the Lower Eel River Watershed (LERW) to track water quality trends using the Hoosier Riverwatch methods. The Clay County SWCD will develop and conduct an educational and outreach program which includes, field days or workshops. The SWCD will develop and distribute press releases to distribute to watershed residents to promote cost-share programs, field days, BMPs, and any other watershed activities or information. column31: ENVIRONMENT, GREAT LAKES, AND ENERGY, MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF
column55: This agreement provides assistance to the Michigan Department of Environment Great Lakes; Energy (DEGLE) to implement its project to support the Great Lakes Restoration Initiative (GLRI) to protect and restore the chemical, physical and biological integrity of the Great Lakes Basin ecosystem.  Specifically, DEGLE will develop and implement Lakewide Action Management Plans (LAMPs) as well as the Remedial Action Plans (RAPs) for associated Areas of Concern (AOC). The Department will assess ecosystems, quality assurance data, and remediate problems in order to delist Beneficial Use Impairments (BUIs).  Some of the workplan activities include: 1) Coordination of the LAMPs for Lakes Superior, Michigan, Huron, Erie and participation in LAMP related programs such as conferences and training; 2) Coordination of the RAP program for twelve AOCs and implementation of the delisting strategy for Michigan's AOCs toward delisting process; and 3) Increase public awareness and participation in Great Lakes restoration programs by overseeing the development of information and educational materials on the AOC and LAMP programs.

column90:
This project proposes to replace approximately 28,000 LF of existing 2", 4", 6", and 8" problematic and 8" undersized waterlines in Edmonton's distribution system. The line replacements will include the following: 6,300 LF of 8" and 6" PVC on Highway 80 North; 2,200 LF of 6" PVC on Greensburg Street; 3,400 LF of 6" PVC on West Stockton & Miller Streets; 3,500 LF of 6" PVC on Highway 640; 1,500 LF of 8" PVC on Highway 90 and 11,600 LF of 4" PVC on  Lonestar Ridge Road. The existing control / pressure reducing station on Highway 3234 will be also replaced. 
 
 The project will also extend approximately 15,100 LF of new 3" waterlines to create two (2) new loops to improve water quality and eliminate dead end waterlines. The new line construction will include: 7,100 LF of 3" PVC on Peckerwood Ridge Road and 8,000 LF of 3" PVC on Roy Grider Road.
 
 In addition to waterline replacements and extensions, this project will rehab, construct, and decommission water tanks and pump stations to improve water quality, pressure, and efficiency in the distribution system. One new water tank will be constructed, four (4) existing water tanks will be rehabilitated or modified, and one existing water tank will be decommissioned. Two existing pump stations will be replaced with upgraded pump stations, one pump station will be modified, and one pump station will be eliminated. SCADA will be upgraded or modified on all new, rehabilitated, or modified tanks and pump stations.
 
 The existing 200,000 gallon Edmonton tank and 100,000 gallon Gascon tank will be completely rehabilitated including miscellaneous structural repairs, new interior and exterior coatings, control valve vaults and piping modification. The existing turnover issues at the 100,000 Gallon Harvey Estes tank and 100,000 Gallon Hickory Ridge tank will be also addressed through piping modifications. The piping and control valve arraignments at all four (4) existing tanks will be modified such that the tanks will fill near the top and drain from the bottom of the bowl. This will greatly improve the turnover and reduce the production of disinfection byproducts. A new Summer Shade 250,000 gallon elevated storage tank will replace the existing 100,000 gallon structure to address inadequate storage and alleviate pressure issues in portions of the distribution system. 
 
 The existing Highway 90 booster pump station that fills the Summer Shade tank will be replaced with a new station, increasing the capacity from 120 GPM to approximately 225 GPM.  The existing Harvey Estes pump station, that fills the Gason and Hickory Ridge tanks will be also be replaced new station, increasing the capacity from 250 GPM to approximately 300 GPM. The existing Harvey Estes pump station will remain and be modified only for use in supplying fire service to an industrial user.

column46: Nonprofit with 501C3 IRS Status (Other than an Institution of Higher Education)
column55: This project will determine the metabolic activities of key xenobiotic-metabolizing enzymes in transgenic knockout zebrafish, often used in toxicity assessments. Parent and primary metabolite profiles for top hit compounds will be determined, and more detailed kinetic assays will be performed on them. A novel multiplexed multidimensional GCxGC-MS identification will characterize the metabolite profiles for selected individual compounds, and will be usable for others.
column56: 66.509: SCIENCE TO ACHIEVE RESULTS (STAR) RESEARCH PROGRAM
column81: Private University or College,Non-Profit Organization,Educational Institution
column90:
I am greatly interested in the evolution and function of cytochrome P450 enzymes in
 aquatic species and I have been using zebrafish as a model species in my research for the
 past 12 years. I am currently funded through the Canadaâ  s Natural Sciences and Engineering
 Research council on three major awards that focus on novel cytochrome P450 enzymes in
 fish and aquatic annelids (Discovery grant), the impacts of temperature on fish development
 (Collaborative Research and Development grant) and fetal programming of low dose radiation
 (Collaborative Research and Development grant); I have additional funding through the
 Department of Fisheries and Oceans Canadaâ  s National Contaminants Advisory Group on the
 impacts of temperature on metal toxicity in Arctic fish species.
 My research expertise is in the area of aquatic toxicology and cytochrome P450 (CYP)
 enzymes. For the past 12 years, we have undertaken a number of studies on the effects of
 human drugs on fish. These studies have examined developmental, reproductive and
 physiological effects of human drugs and zebrafish have been the central species of study.
 Our fundamental work on cytochrome P450 enzymes has provided a major foundation and
 tools for the proposed research. We have expressed zebrafish CYP1 and CYP3 enzymes in
 bacterial systems and developed a high throughput screening approach to determine
 substrates of these enzymes. This expertise in heterologous expression and high throughput
 screening with CYP enzymes will be deployed in this grant to assess metabolism of
 contaminants from the EPAâ  s tox cast libraries. This collaboration will provide an excellent
 opportunity to study xenobiotic metabolism of environmental contaminants of concern, an
 area that is synergistic with our toxicological studies in zebrafish. One of the impacts of our
 proposed studies will include providing data that is essential for toxicokinetics in
 environmental studies on contaminants.
 My research on CYPs has involved genomic, computational and functional studies aimed to
 understand the evolution and function of this important gene superfamily. My laboratory
 primarily focuses on aquatic species. In genomic and computation studies, we have
 Department of Biology Life Sciences Building Phone 905.525.9140 Ext. 20075
 1280 Main Street West Fax 905.522.6066
 Hamilton, Ontario, http://www.mcmaster.ca
 Canada L8S 4K1 E-Mail: joanna.wilson@mcmaster.ca
 completed genome annotations either at the CYP family level (e.g. CYP2 and CYP4 family
 evolutionary studies) or at the species level to understand the CYP complement. Most
 recently, we have annotated and performed phylogenetic analyses of the CYPome from an
 aquatic annelid, Capitella telata. Our work has most recently focused on annotating the round
 goby and Cnidarian (hydra, moon jelly, coral) genomes.
 In functional CYP studies, we have developed a high throughput screening (HTS) approach to
 determine CYP function using expressed proteins. My lab has successfully expressed all five
 zebrafish CYP1s, CYP3A65, and CYP3C1 proteins in bacteria. The expression system we
 use is robust and we are continuing to expand the number of CYPs that we express from
 zebrafish for functional studies. We are happy to bring our expertise to your project to
 express and characterize CYP mediated metabolism for this proposal; note that only one
 enzyme will be de novo expressed in this project as we have previously expressed the
 majority needed for this research. Our high throughput screening approach has been carefully
 developed using the zebrafish CYP1A protein. Our existing screening data used a chemical
 library that contains natural products and pharmaceutical compounds; we are pleased to
 utilize a chemical library of contaminants for your proposed studies and expand our
 toxicokinetic data to contaminants of concern. My lab is ideally suited to collaborate on this as
 we have the most extensive empirical data on zebrafish CYP1A metabolism available.

column55: This agreement will provide assistance to the Vermont Department of Environmental Conservation (VTDEC) in its efforts to reduce diesel emissions and exposure throughout the State of Vermont.  VTDEC will initiate work under this program with a series of open solicitations to local, state, and regional agencies or departments, as well as businesses operating primarily in Vermont. The program will prioritize fleets operating in high population areas, where sensitive populations are located, and in areas that receive a disproportionate quantity of air pollution from diesel fleets. Eligible diesel vehicles, engines, and equipment include verified emission control technologies such as exhaust controls, cleaner fuels, and engine upgrades, verified idle reduction technologies, verified aerodynamic technologies and low rolling resistance tires, certified engine replacements, and/or certified vehicle or equipment replacement. column55: This project intends to conduct mobile monitoring in Southeast Michigan to delineate local scale HAP concentration gradients and generate pollution profiles and emission source signatures of target sources. The project narrative listed eight facilities which will be included in the characterization effort. Plans are to assess the relative contributions of the target sources to ambient concentrations of HAPs and distinguish their contributions to ambient exposure from other primary and secondary sources (such as Canadian emissions). Longer term outcomes include control strategies for HAP emission reductions, and specific EJ communities are noted. Secondary benefits are supporting ozone attainment efforts. This project has strong community involvement, through use of University of Michigan as sub-awardee, where community interactions will affect some of the final study design and allow for easy transfer of study results to community. column90:
Wei Wu will be responsible for developing models to predict coastal wetland distributions under different sea-level rise and restoration scenarios. The model will be based on Wu et al.2017 but incorporate traditional ecological knowledge (TEK) at certain locations where the
 biophysical data are not available or have large uncertainties. The integration will be facilitated
 by developing a BBN to record the TEK. The BBN belongs to a class of graphical models, which allow an intuitive representations of the probabilistic structure of multivariate data using directed
 acyclic graphs with nodes treated as continuous or discrete random variables (Schmitt and Brugere 2013, Scutari and Denis 2015). Nodes are connected in parent-child (predictive)relationships, represented by arrows. Except for decision and utility nodes, a child node (where
 the arrows are pointed to) has a conditional probability distribution (CPD) given the parent nodes (where the arrows are pointed from). The CPD will be derived based on the TEK (expert options). The node information will be updated into the posterior distributions using Bayes' rules of joint probabilities. The resulting BBN will include all the factors which the knowledgeable indigenous people think are important for coastal wetland vulnerability, such as water levels,temperature, and existence of oil pipelines etc. The integrated model will be utilized to evaluate short- (5 years) and long-term (multi-decades) coastal wetland change under different scenarios,including relative sea-level rise scenarios and restoration scenarios. This will not only facilitate the selection of restoration projects that will be best implemented during the duration of the proposed project, but also enhance the development of the T-CRI.
 Wei Wu will also participate in the workshops, and help collect TEK. She will disseminate the research in publication and conference presentation.

column56: 66.040: DIESEL EMISSIONS REDUCTION ACT (DERA) STATE GRANTS; 66.040: STATE CLEAN DIESEL GRANT PROGRAM
column90:
AEA will provide funding and technical assistance to AVEC to replace one engine in Grayling, Alaska.
 Community Existing Engine Replacement Engine
 Grayling Cummins LTA 10 Detroit Diesel S60
 (uncontrolled) (Nonroad Tier 2)
 168 kw Prime 236 kw Prime
 This project will take place in five steps:
 ï · Task 1: Design and identify specifications.
 ï · Task 2: Engine/generator procurement â   Purchase engine, generator and associated equipment,
 including any required assembly and testing. AVEC shall conduct Procurement per 2 CFR
 200.320. The Authority will assist the community to the extent required to meet procurement
 requirements and to ensure a successful project.
 ï · Task 3: Transport â   Ship engine/generator and materials to Grayling.
 ï · Task 4: Installation and commissioning â   Install engine/generator
 ï · Task 5: Project close out deliverables.
 The engine replaced will be scrapped or rendered permanently disabled within ninety (90) days of
 replacement. Cutting a three-inch by three-inch hole in the engine block (the part of the engine containing
 the cylinders) is the preferred scrapping method.
 Evidence of appropriate disposal (such as digital photos of the engine tag showing the serial number,
 engine family number, and engine model year and the of the destroyed engine block) is required along
 with a signed certificate of destruction is required in a final report submitted to AEA.

column90: The proposed project includes implementation of two energy efficiency recommendations included in the Energy Evaluation performed by Process Energy Services, LLC (January 2018). Energy Conservation Measure (ECM) #1 includes taking two of the wastewater treatment facility's existing four lagoons off-line and replacing the existing 74 diffusers in primary lagoon #1. ECM #3 includes replacing the existing hot water heater servicing the lab and bathroom sinks with an on-demand electric water heater. The energy efficiency measures to be implemented by this project are expected to reduce energy consumption by approximately 50%, resulting in savings of over 200,000 KWh per year.  Additionally, the reduction of the wastewater treatment facility's energy consumption will benefit the environment by providing a reduction in greenhouse gas emissions including C02, N20 and CH4.

column90:
The Vanderburgh County SWCD will produce a WMP for the Lower Pigeon watershed, HUCs 0514020203. 
 
 Objectives
 
 Vanderburgh County SWCD plans to improve water quality in the Lower Pigeon Creek Watershed by accomplishing three main objectives over the course of two years. 1) Develop a Watershed Management Plan 2) Water Quality Monitoring 3) Increase Public Awareness and Stewardship Through Outreach and Education.
 
 Methods
 An Education and Outreach program will be developed holding workshops/field days, steering committee meetings, develop and distribute cost-share announcement mailings. Host an annual tour at the City of Evansville water treatment plant. Manage a website and social media updates. Host  a field day or workshop.  Conduct Hoosier Riverwatch monitoring. 
 variety of dissemination methods will be utilized including: newspaper advertisements, brochures, social media, e-newsletters, and other relevant forms of communication, as needed. Media releases will be performed at least quarterly.

column90: Whatcom County Public Works will implement a Drainage Based Management Planning processes in a select few pilot drainages (Bertrand-Schneider, South Fork Nooksack River, and Drayton Harbor). The planning approach will consider several key elements, including water quality, water supply, instream flow, fish habitat, land use, community, floodplain management, climate change, and accountability. Each drainage-based management plan will include a list of early action projects, an effectiveness monitoring plan, implementation schedule, and funding strategy. The work of this planning effort will help guide watershed protections and enhancements and support improved certainty around water use and availability in the WRIA 1 watershed.

column90:
The Gibson County SWCD will produce a WMP for the Highland Pigeon watershed, HUCs 051402020101,02,03,04,05,06 and 07. 
 
 Objectives
 
 Gibson County SWCD plans to improve water quality in the Highland Pigeon Watershed by accomplishing three main objectives over the course of two years. 1) Develop a Watershed Management Plan 2) Water Quality Monitoring 3) Increase Public Awareness and Stewardship Through Outreach and Education.
 
 Methods
 
 The WMP will serve as a compiled analysis of all baseline data, newly collected monitoring data, land use information, resource concerns, and stakeholder input. As well as expanding on existing current data from the LARE grant, and IDEMs TMDL. It will clearly outline all information necessary for the determination of critical areas within the watershed. 
 
 An Education and Outreach program will be developed holding workshops/field days, steering committee meetings, develop and distribute cost-share announcement mailings. Attend partner and regional decision-maker meetings. Manage a website and social media updates. Host demonstration days/field days/workshop and conduct a booth at local county fairs.  A
 variety of dissemination methods will be utilized including: printed media updates, newspaper advertisements, updates to local
 governing bodies, brochures, social media, fliers, email updates, and other relevant forms of communication, as needed. Media
 releases will be performed at least quarterly.

Grant funding received will be used to supplement existing resources to ensure state-wide implementation and critical sampling at the most vulnerable locations, including schools and childcare programs in low-income areas and provide for sampling at daycares located within elemen

column55: The Ohio EPA Division of Surface Water will partner with local governments, local soil and water conservation districts (SWCDs), and the Ohio State University (OSU) to implement six non-point source pollution projects in the Maumee Watershed. These projects will reduce nutrient runoff into Lake Erie by implementing structural, agricultural conservation practices focused on preventing gully erosion and increasing the treatment and retention of runoff water. Altogether, these projects will result in an annual load reduction of approximately 6103 pounds of nitrogen, 1307 pounds of phosphorus, and 1078 tons of sediment and capture approximately 1 million gallons of stormwater runoff annually. Additionally, up to 14 Nonpoint Source Implementation Strategy (NPS-IS) plans will be developed for nearby watersheds.

column55: This agreement provides support to the State of New Hampshire to implement its state nonpoint source management program developed under the Clean Water Act Section 319. This 319(h) grant is used for the implementation of the State of New Hampshires nonpoint source management program. Nonpoint source implementation projects include best management practice (BMP) installations for stormwater, sediment, pesticide and fertilizer control, a variety of other structural and non-structural practices, watershed planning, monitoring, technology demonstrations, and a variety of education/outreach programs.  This agreement provides support to the State of New Hampshire (DES) to implement its state nonpoint source management program developed under the Clean Water Act Section 319.  This 319(h) grant is used for the implementation of the State of New Hampshires nonpoint source management program.  Implementation includes, but is not limited to, installation of Best Management Practices (BMP) to reduce pollution loads to public waters (State, WOTUS, etc).  This agreement provides support to the State of New Hampshire to implement its nonpoint source management program, focusing on watersheds with water quality impairments caused by polluted runoff from nonpoint sources.  Nonpoint source implementation projects include best management practice (BMP) installations for stormwater, sediment, pesticide and fertilizer control, a variety of other structural and non-structural practices, watershed planning, monitoring,technology demonstrations, and a variety of education/outreach programs.  Note that this is an application for two fiscal years of funding, FY2020 and FY2021. This is per the fairly new policy allowing for two year grant applications for 40 CFR Part 35 STAG programs.
column56: 66.460: NONPOINT SOURCE IMPLEMENTATION GRANTS
column90: Lake Sunapee, which serves as a drinking water source for the Town of Sunapee, is currently listed as impaired for aquatic life due to inadequate dissolved oxygen (DO) concentrations. In 2020, LSPA completed a watershed management plan that prioritized a list of stormwater runoff improvement projects that will reduce nutrient pollutant load reductions to Lake Sunapee when implemented. In this second phase of implementation, LSPA will be working cooperatively with key stakeholders in the watershed to complete two projects that achieve pollutant load reductions. This crucial step will make progress toward meeting the water quality goal outlined in the watershed plan. The sites are sediment reduction and stabilization of Gardner Bay Road in Sunapee and tiered sediment traps along the slope of Pine Cliff Road in Newbury. LSPA will be collaborating with the Granliden Community Association and the Newbury Highway Department to implement the proposed best management practices at these sites.

This award will help the New England Interstate Water Pollution Control Commission's (NEIWPCC's) Lake Champlain Basin Program (LCBP) staff to accomplish the following goals:  1) coordinate the continued exchange of State, Federal and local perspectives and concerns on LCBP programs and activities; 2) advise the Steering Committee, States of Vermont and New York, and the Environmental Protection Agency of progress toward achieving objectives of LCBP's Work Plans and other activities; 3) reduce phosphorus inputs to Lake Champlain to promote a healthy and diverse ecosystem and provide for sustainable human use and enjoyment of the Lake; 4) reduce toxic contamination to protect public health and the Lake Champlain ecosystem; 5) promote a basin-wide perspective on water quality issues of regional and national importance; 6) coordinate efforts of water pollution control experts to assist in evaluating the spread of invasive sp

column90: The project includes Tier 1 mapping of submerged aquatic vegetation (SAV) for eastern Long Island Sound including Little Narragansett Bay in Rhode Island and the Peconic Estuary (PEC) in New York. Mapping the distribution and extent of SAV is a critical 1st step in understanding, managing, and protecting shallow-subtidal estuarine habitats. Tier 1 is the smallest scale for mapping SAV, utilizing true-color aerial orthoimagery whereby spectral and spatial signatures of SAV are interpreted and delinieated.

column4: Q: Excluded from tracking (uses non-emergency/non-disaster designated appropriations)
column55: This agreement provides funding to the State of Indiana Department of Environmental Management to carry out its program to maintain, protect, and improve the water quality of its rivers, lakes, streams, groundwater, and other waterbodies. The environmental benefits of this program include preventing degradation of unimpaired waterbodies and reducing the number of impaired waterbodies in the state. Activities include collecting fish tissue data from waters throughout the state of Indiana to support multiple water quality management objectives, purchase monitoring equipment to deploy at three regional monitoring network sites, and fund a contractor with the ability to combine several different data sets for Indiana lakes into a single master spreadsheet file to use in developing an attribute-rich, high-resolution Indiana Reach Index (a geospatial data layer at 1:24,000 scale) for lakes.
column56: 66.419: WATER POLLUTION CONTROL STATE, INTERSTATE, AND TRIBAL PROGRAM SUPPORT
column90: IDEM is working with U.S. EPA to identify coolwater streams in Indiana and modify new biological indices for coolwater streams. Potential coolwater streams will be identified by using the temperature tipping points for coolwater taxa and modeled stream temperature data. Stream temperature models and tools used to identify coolwater streams will be validated by deploying temperature loggers and collecting biological assemblages at sites around the State. Following data collection, new biotic indices will be modified to accurately evaluate biological assemblage expectations for coolwater streams. To enhance this project and conduct aquatic life use assessments, IDEM is proposing to use FFY20 Monitoring Initiative Funds to analyze water samples collected at coolwater sites in 2021. IDEM is requesting $61,494 for the analysis of general chemistry, dissolved metals, and nutrients at an IDEM contract lab. The project will enhance Indianaâ  s monitoring strategy by providing chemical data with biological assemblage information on coolwater streams to appropriately revise biological indices. The data will also be used to assess aquatic life use in IDEMâ  s Integrated Report, thus satisfying 305(b) and 303(d) reporting requirements to U.S. EPA. The purpose of this project is to analyze water samples for general chemistry, dissolved metals, and nutrients at an IDEM contract lab for sites sampled in 2021 throughout the State of Indiana for developing Coolwater IBI metrics for biological assemblages. Site locations have yet to be determined; however, there are potentially 45 total sites. The grant funds requested for this project ($61,494) will be used for the analysis of 159 samples for general chemistry, dissolved metals, and nutrients with data delivered in an electronic data deliverable (EDD) format compatible with the IDEM Assessment Information Management System (AIMS).

Restore America's Estuaries (RAE) will manage a cooperative agreement that will solicit, award and administer competitive subaward grants between $75,000 and $250,000. The overarching goal of this project is to reduce threats to the ecological and economic well-being of coastal and estuarine areas by advancing the implementation of NEP Comprehensive Conservation and Management Plans (CCMPs) and/or state or local-approved watershed management plans within the geographic areas defined as NEP Coastal Watersheds.

The environmental benefits of this program include preventing degradation of unimpaired waterbodies and reducing the number of impaired waterbodies in the state. Activities include collecting fish tissue data from waters throughout the state of Indiana to support multiple water quality management objectives, purchase monitoring equipment to deploy at three regional monitoring network sites, and fund a contractor with the ability to combine several different data sets for Indiana lakes into a single master spreadsheet file to use in developing an attribute-rich, high-resolution Indiana Reach Index (a geospatial data layer at 1:24,000 scale) for lakes.
column56: 66.419: WATER POLLUTION CONTROL STATE, INTERSTATE, AND TRIBAL PROGRAM SUPPORT
column90:
The Indiana Department of Environmental Management (IDEM) will purchase monitoring equipment to deploy at three regional monitoring network sites in Indiana. To reduce costs for measuring water levels and performing elevation surveys, the sites will be co-located at USGS gaging stations which are also sampled as part of the IDEM Fixed Station network. The exact sites are not known at this point; however, the table below provides a list of 6 potential sites that may be wadeable and have riffles. As part of the IDEM Fixed Station network, the three sites will be sampled monthly for general chemistry, nutrients, metals and field parameters.
 The purpose of this project is to participate in the U.S. EPA Regional Monitoring Network by purchasing and deploying the equipment necessary to monitor the required parameters. Participation in the Regional Monitoring Network will enhance Indianaâ  s Water Monitoring Strategy by tracking changes in biological, thermal, hydrologic, habitat, and water chemistry data at high quality sites over time with changes in thermal and hydrological conditions. As listed in the Generic Stream Monitoring Network QAPP (U.S. EPA 2016), data from these sites can also be used for:
 â ¢IDEMâ  s Integrated Report, thus satisfying 305(b) and 303(d) reporting requirements to U.S. EPA
 â ¢Informing criteria development or refinement (e.g., defining natural conditions)
 â ¢Quantifying natural variability
 â ¢Investigating relationships between biological, thermal, and hydrologic data
 â ¢Exploring ecosystem responses and recovery from extreme weather events

column31: STATE OF OHIO OFFICE OF BUDGET AND MANAGEMENT STATE ACCOUNTING
column55: The Ohio EPA Division of Surface Water will partner with local governments, local soil and water conservation districts (SWCDs), and the Ohio State University (OSU) to implement six non-point source pollution projects in the Maumee Watershed. These projects will reduce nutrient runoff into Lake Erie by implementing structural, agricultural conservation practices focused on preventing gully erosion and increasing the treatment and retention of runoff water. Altogether, these projects will result in an annual load reduction of approximately 6103 pounds of nitrogen, 1307 pounds of phosphorus, and 1078 tons of sediment and capture approximately 1 million gallons of stormwater runoff annually. Additionally, up to 14 Nonpoint Source Implementation Strategy (NPS-IS) plans will be developed for nearby watersheds.

The project approach and scope of work shall include tasks to evaluate the stated concerns and provide information for the development of the following deliverables. 
 Core tasks for the project to include (1) an evaluation of the existing infrastructure relative to public concerns, including the general condition of the structure, stormwater impacts at the site and other and other related concerns; (2) an assessment of potential impacts of the existing structure relative to flooding, aquatic organism passage and sediment transport; and (3) a hydraulic and hydrologic analysis of the culverts to provide better understanding of the flow regimes at the site and the relationship of this infrastructure to the lake. 
 The main deliverables for this project will include an alternative Analysis Report describing potential alternatives for improvements/replacement of the current infrastructure, including a description of how the alternatives would address the stated concerns, and development of conceptual designs and cost for up to three alternatives.

column90: a Loan for the Innovative Illicit Discharge Detection and Elimination Stormwater Dry Weather Testing Project.  This project will prepare written and electronic procedures for the detection of illicit discharges associated with the New Hampshire Small Municipal Separate Storm Sewer System (MS4) permit. The procedures are specific to dry weather outfall screening and sampling that are a requirement of the permit, specifically MCM #3 Illicit Discharge Detection and Elimination. The project will result in exploring best methods for screening water quality parameters, real-time alternative methods to screen for stormwater pollutants of concern by utilizing optical sensors, and alternative sampling procedures for fecal indicator bacteria. Fecal indicator bacteria are difficult to screen and accurately relate to illicit sanitary sewer connections. The project will utilize the alternative process by using 16S ribosomal RNA. The results of the project will lead to an outfall and interconnection screening and sampling procedure to be included in the City of Dover s Illicit Discharge Detection and Elimination program, which is a requirement of the permit. All procedures and methods will be transferable and shared with all of New Hampshire Small MS4 communities.

column56: 66.475: GULF OF MEXICO PROGRAM
column81: Minority Owned Business,Non-Profit Organization,Native American Owned,American Indian Owned
column90:
Pointe-au-Chien Indian Tribe (PACIT) Scope of Work
 
 As part of this project, PACIT will assist LSU's research team in developing and testing a customized Coastal Resilience Index tool (T-CRI) to assess indigenous community specific vulnerabilities. PACIT will work with the research team to build off of the T-CRI results to inventory and characterize its natural, economic, and human assets critical to resilience, and identify a project or action that strengthens its resilience and can be implemented with project funds. PACIT will also encourage dialog with other indigenous communities about preparedness, response, and recovery.

column90:
Sludge samples collected from active wastewater treatment plants and sludge, soil, and water samples collected from land application sites and nearby drinking water supply wells will be analyzed to determine whether land application of wastewater treatment plant sludges have impacted local groundwater and drinking water quality and whether revisions to the land application rules and procedures are necessary. The results of these analyses will identify impacted water supplies so that corrective actions can be implemented in a timely manner. The Emerging Contaminants Fund will also support this effort by the Residuals Management Section through PFAS testing in wastewater, sludge, and septage. 
 
 Soil, sediment, groundwater, drinking water, and surface water samples are collected at CERCLA sites to investigate source areas, assess the extent of contaminants, and evaluate attenuation trends during investigation, remediation, and long-term monitoring programs. The analyses for Industrial Pretreatment will allow the NHDES to comply with the Agreement for the Treatment of Dummer Yard Leachate entered into between the NHDES and the City of Berlin, NH on April 23, 2007. Volatile organic compound (VOC) analyses will be performed statewide to continue assessment and monitoring of methyl tert-butyl ether (MtBE) impacts to drinking water supply wells. Almost 10,000 water supply wells have been assessed since program inception. Detectable levels of MtBE are identified in approximately 12% of the wells sampled. 
 
 This new contract will allow the sludge analysis and hazardous waste cleanup funds, CERCLA Maintenance and Program Funds, Industrial Pretreatment Funds, MtBE Remediation Settlement Funds, and Emerging Contaminant Funds to continue to be used to perform these functions at various sites and facilities throughout the state of NH.
 
 NHDES issued an Invitation to Bid on February 12, 2021 that included a requirement for submission of a qualifications package as well as a bid cost. The Invitation to Bid was posted on the Department of Administrative Servicesâ   Procurement and Support Services website and a link to the website posting was emailed out to three laboratories comprising the current contract laboratory and the previous two contract laboratories.
   
 Six laboratories submitted bid packages. The packages were reviewed by a committee consisting of four NHDES staff to determine completeness and the bidderâ  s qualifications to provide the required services. The bid packages were scored in accordance with the Award Criteria specified in the Invitation to Bid. One laboratory was selected for contract award based on the scores and pricing, summarized in Attachment A.
 
 Alpha Analytical, Inc. holds the requisite accreditations and has demonstrated that it has the staffing and laboratory capabilities to perform the analyses in accordance with the specifications set forth by NHDES.
 
 The contract has been approved by the Department of Justice as to form, substance, and execution.

column55: This agreement provides support to the State of New Hampshire to implement its state nonpoint source management program developed under the Clean Water Act Section 319. This 319(h) grant is used for the implementation of the State of New Hampshires nonpoint source management program. Nonpoint source implementation projects include best management practice (BMP) installations for stormwater, sediment, pesticide and fertilizer control, a variety of other structural and non-structural practices, watershed planning, monitoring, technology demonstrations, and a variety of education/outreach programs.  This agreement provides support to the State of New Hampshire (DES) to implement its state nonpoint source management program developed under the Clean Water Act Section 319.  This 319(h) grant is used for the implementation of the State of New Hampshires nonpoint source management program.  Implementation includes, but is not limited to, installation of Best Management Practices (BMP) to reduce pollution loads to public waters (State, WOTUS, etc).  This agreement provides support to the State of New Hampshire to implement its nonpoint source management program, focusing on watersheds with water quality impairments caused by polluted runoff from nonpoint sources.  Nonpoint source implementation projects include best management practice (BMP) installations for stormwater, sediment, pesticide and fertilizer control, a variety of other structural and non-structural practices, watershed planning, monitoring,technology demonstrations, and a variety of education/outreach programs.  Note that this is an application for two fiscal years of funding, FY2020 and FY2021. This is per the fairly new policy allowing for two year grant applications for 40 CFR Part 35 STAG programs.
column56: 66.460: NONPOINT SOURCE IMPLEMENTATION GRANTS
column90:
NHDES issued a Request for Proposals (RFP) for the 2021 Watershed Assistance Grants program. The ten proposals received were ranked based on the criteria included in the RFP: water quality improvement or protection; cost/benefit ratio; local capacity to complete the project; relative value or significance of the water body; and general quality and thoroughness of the proposal. Based on the results of the selection process and available federal grant funding levels, eight implementation projects were selected to receive funding. Please see Attachment B for a list of project rankings and NHDES review team members.
 
 Watershed Assistance Grants focus on the reduction of nonpoint source (NPS) pollution. NPS pollution occurs when rainfall, snowmelt, or irrigation waters travel through the ground or across land, transporting materials that are then introduced into groundwater or deposited into rivers, lakes, and coastal waters. Pollutants can include chemicals, sediments, nutrients, and toxins that often have harmful effects on drinking water supplies, recreation, fisheries, and wildlife. Land development or changes in land use can also cause NPS pollution by disrupting the natural hydrology of a water body, increasing impervious surfaces, and contributing to the loss of aquatic habitat. Watershed Assistance Grants address NPS pollution by promoting responsible land use practices on the watershed scale.
 
 Chapel Brook is an impaired water body in North Hampton, NH that has experienced extensive flooding and neighborhood isolation during severe storm events. This project will retrofit the existing culvert at the outlet of Chapel Brook under Route 1A to the Atlantic Ocean, which will improve drainage and tidal flushing in and out of the marsh without increasing flood risk. Increased tidal flows will allow the stagnant and near-permanently flooded salt marsh of Philbrick Pond to drain and replenish according to natural tide cycles, which it is currently unable to do. In addition, the project partners will work to develop a salt marsh restoration design for Philbrick Pond and implement an initial design phase. This restoration design will identify techniques and strategies to correct the long-term impacts of tidal regime modification, past agricultural uses and mosquito control practices that continue to degrade the health of the marsh and its water quality.
 
 The total project costs are budgeted at $114,189. NHDES will provide $68,500 (60%) of the project costs through a federal grant, and The Nature Conservancy will provide the remaining costs through cash and in-kind services. A budget is provided in Attachment A. 
 
 In the event that federal funds become no longer available, general funds will not be requested to support this program. The agreement has been approved by the Office of the Attorney General as to form, execution, and content.

column90: The proposed corrective action is to rehabilitate or reconstruct sections of lines of the existing sewer infrastructure in the critical areas of the Town. A sewer study will include field investigation efforts involving smoke testing, TV camera inspection of lines, cleaning, to identify potential service line repairs, line replacement and lining, point repairs and manhole sealing alternatives. The reduction of the inflow and infiltration by system rehabilitation will improve the system's transport capabilities to handle the sewage flow generated in this area. The repairs to the wastewater lines will reduce the related O&M costs of the pump station serving not only for this area, but for downstream pump stations and lines transporting sewage flows to the Town's treatment facility and will allow the treatment of the wastewater more effectively in wet weather by delivering less rain water to the downstream plant.

column55: The Southeast New England Program (SNEP) Stormwater Technical Assistance Network (STAN) brings together regional experts in stormwater management, financing, water quality and habitat restoration, green infrastructure, low impact development, and environmental restoration. The New England Environmental Finance Center (NE EFC) will administer and manage STAN, but the majority of SNEP funds will be distributed to committed partners in the SNEP area to carry out tasks. STAN partners will come together as a network of partner-providers offering a full complement of technical and financial services to municipalities, tribes, and organizations in the SNEP region, including technical assistance provided by a pool of vetted service providers/contractors who will competitively bid services to ensure a high caliber of talent and quality work. STAN will also expand upon established partnerships across Southeast New England, serving as a clearinghouse for the region on stormwater management and financing, green infrastructure, low impact development, and water quality and habitat restoration activities.

column55: These funds to the Texas State Soil and Water Conservation Board contain activities that complement existing environmental program grants such as the CWA Section 319 Grants. Specifically, water quality in Deer Creek currently exceeds recreational use standards and, as a result, a Recreational Use Attainability Analysis was conducted in 2012. The report shows that primary contact recreation occurs on the waterbody (https://www.tceq.texas.gov/assets/public/waterquality/standards/ruaa/brazos5/DeerCreek_recommendation.pdf) indicating that standards will not change. Due to a lack of water quality data available for Deer Creek, additional surface water quality monitoring data is necessary to provide a good foundation for future watershed planning and implementation activities. Additionally, expanded data collection will allow for more accurate assessment of waterbody conditions and aid in identifying potential causes and sources of pollution.
