column90:
NHDES issued a Request for Proposals (RFP) for the 2020 Watershed Assistance Grants program. The five proposals received were ranked based on the criteria included in the RFP: water quality improvement or protection; cost/benefit ratio; local capacity to complete the project; relative value or significance of the water body; and general quality and thoroughness of the proposal. Based on the results of the selection process and available federal grant funding levels, five implementation projects were selected to receive funding. Please see Attachment B for a list of project rankings and NHDES review team members.
 
 Watershed Assistance Grants focus on the reduction of nonpoint source (NPS) pollution. NPS pollution occurs when rainfall, snowmelt, or irrigation waters travel through the ground or across land, transporting materials that are then introduced into groundwater or deposited into rivers, lakes, and coastal waters. Pollutants can include chemicals, sediments, nutrients, and toxins that often have harmful effects on drinking water supplies, recreation, fisheries, and wildlife. Land development or changes in land use can also cause NPS pollution by disrupting the natural hydrology of a water body, increasing impervious surfaces, and contributing to the loss of aquatic habitat. Watershed Assistance Grants address NPS pollution by promoting responsible land use practices on the watershed scale.
 
 Lake Warren is currently listed on the NHDES List of Impaired Waters as not supporting its designated use of Aquatic Life Integrity due to excessive concentrations of phosphorus and Chlorophyll-a. In the Lake Warren Watershed Management Plan (WMP), it was determined that a 28 percent reduction in phosphorus loading to Lake Warren was needed to restore water quality. This project will reduce pollutants through implementation of best management practices (BMPs) at select sites that have been identified in the WMP as being medium or high impact and by conducting outreach events to provide information to residents and interested parties on ways in which they can make changes to care for the lake and take steps that will help to improve water quality. The selected sites include stormwater management improvements to Arbor Way, a heavily eroded private drive along Pine Cliff Road, conceptual design for improvements to Pine Cliff Road reducing the road width to create a larger buffer and walkway between the edge of the road and the shoreline, technical assistance and installation of BMPS at residential, shoreland properties or town properties/right of ways.

column46: Nonprofit with 501C3 IRS Status (Other than an Institution of Higher Education)
column55: This project will determine the metabolic activities of key xenobiotic-metabolizing enzymes in transgenic knockout zebrafish, often used in toxicity assessments. Parent and primary metabolite profiles for top hit compounds will be determined, and more detailed kinetic assays will be performed on them. A novel multiplexed multidimensional GCxGC-MS identification will characterize the metabolite profiles for selected individual compounds, and will be usable for others.
column56: 66.509: SCIENCE TO ACHIEVE RESULTS (STAR) RESEARCH PROGRAM
column81: Private University or College,Non-Profit Organization,Educational Institution
column90:
I am greatly interested in the evolution and function of cytochrome P450 enzymes in
 aquatic species and I have been using zebrafish as a model species in my research for the
 past 12 years. I am currently funded through the Canadaâ  s Natural Sciences and Engineering
 Research council on three major awards that focus on novel cytochrome P450 enzymes in
 fish and aquatic annelids (Discovery grant), the impacts of temperature on fish development
 (Collaborative Research and Development grant) and fetal programming of low dose radiation
 (Collaborative Research and Development grant); I have additional funding through the
 Department of Fisheries and Oceans Canadaâ  s National Contaminants Advisory Group on the
 impacts of temperature on metal toxicity in Arctic fish species.
 My research expertise is in the area of aquatic toxicology and cytochrome P450 (CYP)
 enzymes. For the past 12 years, we have undertaken a number of studies on the effects of
 human drugs on fish. These studies have examined developmental, reproductive and
 physiological effects of human drugs and zebrafish have been the central species of study.
 Our fundamental work on cytochrome P450 enzymes has provided a major foundation and
 tools for the proposed research. We have expressed zebrafish CYP1 and CYP3 enzymes in
 bacterial systems and developed a high throughput screening approach to determine
 substrates of these enzymes. This expertise in heterologous expression and high throughput
 screening with CYP enzymes will be deployed in this grant to assess metabolism of
 contaminants from the EPAâ  s tox cast libraries. This collaboration will provide an excellent
 opportunity to study xenobiotic metabolism of environmental contaminants of concern, an
 area that is synergistic with our toxicological studies in zebrafish. One of the impacts of our
 proposed studies will include providing data that is essential for toxicokinetics in
 environmental studies on contaminants.
 My research on CYPs has involved genomic, computational and functional studies aimed to
 understand the evolution and function of this important gene superfamily. My laboratory
 primarily focuses on aquatic species. In genomic and computation studies, we have
 Department of Biology Life Sciences Building Phone 905.525.9140 Ext. 20075
 1280 Main Street West Fax 905.522.6066
 Hamilton, Ontario, http://www.mcmaster.ca
 Canada L8S 4K1 E-Mail: joanna.wilson@mcmaster.ca
 completed genome annotations either at the CYP family level (e.g. CYP2 and CYP4 family
 evolutionary studies) or at the species level to understand the CYP complement. Most
 recently, we have annotated and performed phylogenetic analyses of the CYPome from an
 aquatic annelid, Capitella telata. Our work has most recently focused on annotating the round
 goby and Cnidarian (hydra, moon jelly, coral) genomes.
 In functional CYP studies, we have developed a high throughput screening (HTS) approach to
 determine CYP function using expressed proteins. My lab has successfully expressed all five
 zebrafish CYP1s, CYP3A65, and CYP3C1 proteins in bacteria. The expression system we
 use is robust and we are continuing to expand the number of CYPs that we express from
 zebrafish for functional studies. We are happy to bring our expertise to your project to
 express and characterize CYP mediated metabolism for this proposal; note that only one
 enzyme will be de novo expressed in this project as we have previously expressed the
 majority needed for this research. Our high throughput screening approach has been carefully
 developed using the zebrafish CYP1A protein. Our existing screening data used a chemical
 library that contains natural products and pharmaceutical compounds; we are pleased to
 utilize a chemical library of contaminants for your proposed studies and expand our
 toxicokinetic data to contaminants of concern. My lab is ideally suited to collaborate on this as
 we have the most extensive empirical data on zebrafish CYP1A metabolism available.

column55: The Targeted Air Shed (TAS) project for Logan UT/ID Cache Valley Community is part of EPA's 2016 TAS Grant Program. The project will reduce PM2.5 air pollution in the Logan UT/ID PM2.5 Nonattainment Area by reducing emissions from road dust, wood combustion, and transportation sources. Strategies include wood stove change-outs, home weatherization, reducing road sanding with the use of salt and brine, installation of Stage I Vapor Recovery in gas stations, and the capital purchase of buses. Community outreach and education will add to the effectiveness of the program.

column55: This action awards federal funds of $2,105,540, of which $489,540 is supplemental funding to support work in Delaware's most effective basins. This award supports Delaware in meeting its nutrient and sediment allocations, with the overall goal of achieving the restoration and protection of the Chesapeake Bay watershed and its living resources. This will be accomplished by implementing Delaware's Watershed Implementation Plans (WIPs) that detail a mix of best management practices (BMPs), wastewater treatment technology upgrades, and other activities necessary to restore and protect the Chesapeake Bay. column90:
The proposed project will replace approximately 28,375LF of waterline, along with valves and fire hydrants, in residential and commercial areas in the Burnside Water System. 
 
 The existing water system along Highland Drive, Childress Drive, and Military Road consists of 2â   galvanized lines that are approximately 40 years old.  These lines do not provide adequate service and they are troublesome to maintain.  These lines will be replaced with 6â   PVC lines, which are needed to provide adequate domestic and fire protection service to that area.
 
 The existing water system along Cliffside Drive and Cumberland Lane consists of 4â   PVC lines that are approximately 40 years old.  These lines do not provide adequate fire protection service to this area.  These lines will be replaced with 6â   PVC lines, which are needed to provide adequate domestic and fire protection service along these streets.
 
 The existing water system along Oak Street, Walnut Street, Elm Street, Ash Street, East Antioch Avenue, West Lakeshore Drive, East Lakeshore Drive and Boland Avenue consists of cast iron lines that were laid in the 1950â  s.  These water lines are clogged with tubercles, which restrict the inside diameter to the point where domestic water service and fire protection services are compromised. Furthermore, there are frequent line breaks, resulting in water loss. This proposed project will replace these lines with 6â   PVC line.  
 
 The existing water system along US 27 (Main Street) and East French Ave consists of cast iron lines that were laid in the 1950â  s.  The water lines along these two roads supply the entire Burnside system.  However, these lines are clogged with tubercles, which restrict the inside diameter to the point where domestic water service and fire protection services are compromised. Furthermore, there are frequent line breaks, resulting in water loss. This proposed project will replace these lines with 8â   PVC line.  
 
 The proposed line size and length along each street is:
 Highland Drive â   560 LF of 6â   PVC water main
 Military Road â   1,225 LF of 6â   PVC water main
 Childress Drive â   1,125 LF of 6â   PVC water main
 Cumberland Lane â   585 LF of 6â   PVC water main
 Cliffside Drive â   3,250 LF of 6â   PVC water main
 East Lakeshore Drive â   3,610 LF of 6â   PVC water main
 West Lakeshore Drive â   5,935 LF of 6â   PVC water main
 Boland Street â   320 LF of 6â   PVC water main
 US 27 (Main Street) â   5,200 LF of 8â   PVC water main
 East French Avenue â   1,060 LF of 8â   PVC water main
 Ash Street â   1,330 LF of 6â   PVC water main
 Walnut Street â   940 LF of 6â   PVC water main
 Oak Street â   885 LF of 6â   PVC water main
 Elm Street â   915 LF of 6â   PVC water main
 East Antioch Avenue â   1,425 LF of 6â   PVC water main

column56: 66.442: ASSISTANCE FOR SMALL AND DISADVANTAGED COMMUNITIES DRINKING WATER GRANT PROGRAM (SDWA 1459A)
column90:
Grant monies totaling $420,000 with a required (45%) state match of $343,636, which will be met with state appropriations from the Drinking Water and Groundwater Trust Fund, have been made available to the New Hampshire Department of Environmental Services (NHDES) through the Water Infrastructure Improvement for the Nation (WIIN) Act, Assistance for Small and Disadvantaged Communities Drinking Water Grant administered by the United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA).  NHDES proposes to use the funds to assist a select list of small and disadvantaged water systems to provide funding assistance for improvements to their drinking water systems necessary to comply with the Safe Drinking Water Act (SDWA), address water supply capacity issues or respond to a drinking water contaminant. 
 
 The Drinking Water and Groundwater Bureau (DWGB) intends to use the grant funds to develop and implement a small/disadvantaged grant program for the neediest water systems in the State. Initially, two community water systems are identified as meeting eligibility requirements for the subawards. Additional eligible recipients will be identified as funding allows.  
 
 In conjunction with a Drinking Water State Revolving Fund (DWSRF) loan Marlborough Estates will use the grant funds for water system improvements including source replacement, and pump house and water storage upgrades. The three existing bedrock wells have all significantly declined in their capacity to provide an adequate supply to the community.  This project will improve water quantity and quality issues as well as improve resiliency.
 
 The South Weare Water Association will use the grant funds for water system improvements including developing a new water supply well with associated infrastructure, controls, and water treatment needs. Additional improvements include water main replacement, meter installation, pump house upgrades and water storage improvements. The water system lacks the capacity to meet even average daily water demands, the community endures frequent and extended water outages, and water is not reliably available. This project will improve water quantity and quality issues as well as improve resiliency and reliability.
 
 In the event that grant funds no longer become available, General funds will not be requested to support this program. This agreement has been approved by the Attorney Generalâ  s Office as to form, substance and execution.  
 
 We respectfully request your approval of this item.

The recipient will provide 40% of this award to regional or interstate watershed management planning agencies for the development and implementation of water quality management plans.

column55: This agreement will provide assistance to the Vermont Department of Environmental Conservation (VTDEC) in its efforts to reduce diesel emissions and exposure throughout the State of Vermont.  VTDEC will initiate work under this program with a series of open solicitations to local, state, and regional agencies or departments, as well as businesses operating primarily in Vermont. The program will prioritize fleets operating in high population areas, where sensitive populations are located, and in areas that receive a disproportionate quantity of air pollution from diesel fleets. Eligible diesel vehicles, engines, and equipment include verified emission control technologies such as exhaust controls, cleaner fuels, and engine upgrades, verified idle reduction technologies, verified aerodynamic technologies and low rolling resistance tires, certified engine replacements, and/or certified vehicle or equipment replacement. All projects will reduce emissions of diesel particulate matter and ot

column56: 66.442: ASSISTANCE FOR SMALL AND DISADVANTAGED COMMUNITIES DRINKING WATER GRANT PROGRAM (SDWA 1459A)
column81: U.S. Local Government,Housing Authorities Public/Tribal,Municipality,City,DOT Certified DBE
column90:
The City is proposing to plan, design, and construct water system improvements to bring the treatment system into compliance with the MCLs for arsenic and fluoride, including installation of improved pumps and chemical dosing system and modifications to the existing reverse osmosis treatment system. The City also proposes to replace the existing chlorination system with a more automated and flexible system for improved disinfection and ease of maintenance.
 
 Proposed distribution system improvements include replacement of approximately 9,545 linear feet of aging water line, replacement of the existing 150,000 gallon elevated storage tank that is leaking and in danger of failure, replacement of one existing 500,000 gallon ground storage tank (GST), and replacement of a second existing 500,000 gallon GST with two 250,000 gallon GSTs. The distribution system improvements will reduce water loss, maintain adequate elevated storage capacity and system pressure for the current population, and add ground storage tank redundancy to allow for flexibility in operations and maintenance.

column55: The Ohio EPA Division of Surface Water will partner with local governments, local soil and water conservation districts (SWCDs), and the Ohio State University (OSU) to implement six non-point source pollution projects in the Maumee Watershed. These projects will reduce nutrient runoff into Lake Erie by implementing structural, agricultural conservation practices focused on preventing gully erosion and increasing the treatment and retention of runoff water. Altogether, these projects will result in an annual load reduction of approximately 6103 pounds of nitrogen, 1307 pounds of phosphorus, and 1078 tons of sediment and capture approximately 1 million gallons of stormwater runoff annually. Additionally, up to 14 Nonpoint Source Implementation Strategy (NPS-IS) plans will be developed for nearby watersheds.

column90: The goal of this project aligns with Strategy 3: ensuring the uninterrupted operation of lift stations during power failures and prolonged power outages specifically, by providing automatic emergency power to 2 lift stations where there is currently no generator. Specific objectives/performance measures include purchasing and installing 2 generators with aluminum enclosures (aluminum is resistant to corrosion by sewer gases) and 2 automatic transfer switches (ATSs) for Lift Stations 6 and 51. Installation of the generators and ATSs will improve the maintenance, operation, and reliability of Hammond's collection system especially during power failures and prolonged power outages.

column55: This agreement is to fund the State of West Virginia&rsquoands Water Quality Management Planning Program. The University of Toledo will assist the City of Toledo with implementation and maintenance plans for
 the trash collection equipment. University of Toledo students will characterize the debris collected at the
 sites during the project period in accordance with established NOAA trash classification protocols
 (quantity, types, and concentration). In addition, the students will track the educational initiatives,
 watershed characteristics, and precipitation patterns during the project period. This information will be
 used to inform future public education initiatives and to guide planning for trash collection device
 implementation and maintenance in the City of Toledo. Dr. Cyndee Gruden has committed her time (0.05
 FTE) and a University of Toledo Graduate Student (0.5 FTE) to this project. They will also participate
 with other team members in the dissemination of project findings at local and regional stakeholder
 meetings and through participation in the Ohio Stormwater Association Annual Conference in May 2021.
 For more information regarding the University of Toledo, visit https://www.utoledo.edu/.

column90:
Natural variations in dissolved 02 stable isotopic composition (81 8  0  2) permits the contributions from different biological processes to be quantified without manipulative experimentation. It has been long known that the 8180 of atmospheric 02 is about-25%0  higher than oceanic water.   More recently this was recognized as the global net consequence of   respiration strongly discriminating against 1 8 0 leaving the atmosphere relatively enriched in 1 8 0 . Photosynthetic 02 is produced by splitting of H20 and has a similar 81 8  0  to environmental  water (-0%0 in the case of seawater).    Hence, net biological 02 production  produces severe 1 8     0
 depletion in dissolved 02. 81 8  0 2 primarily responds to 1) photosynthetic 02 production which
 lowers 81 8  0 2 and 2) respiration which increases 01 8  0 2. The respiration effect in turn is modulated by the proportions of water column and benthic respiration. Increasing importance of benthic respiration attenuates the relationship between 81 8  0 2 and net 02 consumption. As for denitrification, benthic  respiration  produces  little  isotopic fractionation.
 Analysis for 81 8  0 2 is complemented  by measurement of Oi/Ar ratio as the latter is only influenced by net biological production or removal. 02 concentration per se is also affected by physical influences particularly temperature and salinity forced changes in solubility. In our prior LIS work, we saw large summertime variations in 0180 2 coupled to Oi/Ar which is measured simultaneously. Toward the west and at the surface, high Oi/Ar (excess 02) correlated with low 81 8  0 2 as expected from high biological productivity. We will exploit this signal to trace the transfer of photosynthetic 02 via mixing to the subsurface zone. In the bottom  layer, the  relationship between increasing 8180 2 and decreasing excess 02 suggests an overall even partitioning  between benthic and water  column  respiration.
 As part of this project, we will carry out for 81 8  0  2 and 02/Ar. analyses on samples collected from the LIS water column during its research cruises. Our goal here with the other PI's is to geochemically constrain the summertime LIS 02 budget to better understand the conditions that give rise to hypoxia and how they are varying from year to year with reductions in N loading.
 We will directly examine the quantitative contribution of photosynthetic 02 to the hypoxic zone and the relative importance of water column and benthic respiration using 81 8  0  2 and Oi/Ar as tracers for these processes as discussed above.  High precision measurements of 81 8  0 2 and Oi/Ar will be made on septum sealed serum bottles using an automated, on-line gas extraction system coupled to a multicollector IRMS as described in Charoenpong et al. (2014). 01 8  0 2 is determined relative to atmospheric 02 and corrected for ion source effects of varying 02/N2. Excess 02 concentration in ÂµM, the observed [02] minus the equilibrium [02] at in-situ temperature and  salinity as determined from 02/Ar, will be calculated as in Charoenpong et al. (2014). Excess 02 and 81 8  0 2 will be calibrated daily against seawater standards equilibrated with air at fixed temperature. Precision of the measurements (standard deviation) for the samples is generally better than 1 Âµmol L-1 for [02]excess and 0.2%0 for 01 8  0 2.

column90: Public Health-Seattle and King County (PHSKC) will proactively find and fix fecal pollution sources impacting shellfish growing areas. Partnering with Department of Natural Resources and Parks (DNRP), advisory committees, and local community leaders, PHSKC will assess sources of OSS pollution and propose OSS corrections that are accepted by the community, quickly reduce pollution, and are cost-effective. PHSKC will reduce non-point fecal pollution (from poorly-maintained OSS, failing  OSS, pet waste, etc.) by engaging community members in identifying solutions and taking action to protect water quality. The County will focus on proactive work in poverty Bay Shellfish Protection District and continue work on Vashon Island, specifically along Colvos Passage. PHSKC will continue work along East Passage and in other areas  following WDOH Shellfish Program sanitary surveys if time and funding allow

column90: This project, located in the Mississippi North Central watershed, will help in the prioritization of sub-watersheds for future 9-element watershed-based plan development by local shareholders. The Mississippi North Central watershed is approximately 1.1 million acres in size, spans 6 counties, including 65 tributaries- all draining to the Mississippi River. The watershed has been identified as high priority in the Illinois Nutrient Loss reduction Strategy for nitrate-nitrogen. This project will conduct watershed characterization, sub-watershed screening, nutrient and sediment modeling and loading, and stakeholder outreach throughout the 1.1 million acre HUC-08 project area to prioritize the HUC-12 sub watersheds for local watershed stakeholders WBP development after the project is complete.

column56: 66.125: LAKE PONTCHARTRAIN BASIN RESTORATION PROGRAM (PRP)
column90: The project goal and objective is to prepare design plans and specifications for public bid for the St. Jude Sewer Lift Station Upgrades project. Upgrading the station with new electrical controls, emergency generator connection, pumps and piping will reduce the risk of sanitary sewer overflows to help restore the water quality of the Lake Pontchartrain Basin. The design will include a portable generator connection in the new electrical panel for the station. The City has existing portable generators to connect to the station in the event emergency power is needed. The existing lift station site constraints does not allow for a permanent generator to be installed on site. An emergency pump out will be installed on the force main for by-pass pumping. The contractor will be required to submit a by-pass plan for approval by the engineer before any bypass operations can begin.

column55: Perfomance Partnership Grant funds are used by the Utah Department of Environmental Quality (UDEQ) to perform delegated program activities, perform quality assurance activities, and maintain regional and national databases associated with environmental programs. These include Clean Air, Clean Water, Hazardous Waste Management, Safe Drinking Water, Toxics Management and Abatement, and Pollution Prevention. The Performance Partnership Agreement PPA serves as the definative workplan for the Performance Partnership Grant (PPG). As such, the PPA/PPG in tandem provides the State greater flexibility to address its highest environmental priorities, improve environmental performance, achieve administrative savings and strengthen the partnership between the State and the Environmental Protection Agency.

column55: This agreement provides support to the State of New Hampshire to implement its state nonpoint source management program developed under the Clean Water Act Section 319. This 319(h) grant is used for the implementation of the State of New Hampshires nonpoint source management program. Nonpoint source implementation projects include best management practice (BMP) installations for stormwater, sediment, pesticide and fertilizer control, a variety of other structural and non-structural practices, watershed planning, monitoring, technology demonstrations, and a variety of education/outreach programs.  This agreement provides support to the State of New Hampshire (DES) to implement its state nonpoint source management program developed under the Clean Water Act Section 319.  This 319(h) grant is used for the implementation of the State of New Hampshires nonpoint source management program.  Implementation includes, but is not limited to, installation of Best Management Practices (BMP) to reduce pollution loads to public waters (State, WOTUS, etc).  This agreement provides support to the State of New Hampshire to implement its nonpoint source management program, focusing on watersheds with water quality impairments caused by polluted runoff from nonpoint sources.  Nonpoint source implementation projects include best management practice (BMP) installations for stormwater, sediment, pesticide and fertilizer control, a variety of other structural and non-structural practices, watershed planning, monitoring,technology demonstrations, and a variety of education/outreach programs.  Note that this is an application for two fiscal years of funding, FY2020 and FY2021. This is per the fairly new policy allowing for two year grant applications for 40 CFR Part 35 STAG programs.
column56: 66.460: NONPOINT SOURCE IMPLEMENTATION GRANTS
column90:
The Province Lake Watershed Management Plan (PLWMP) defined six Action Plan categories needed to
 reduce Phosphorus loading to impaired Province Lake: Septic Systems, Shoreline Best Management
 Practices, Roads, Municipal Ordinances and Land Conservation, Recreation/Boating and Water Quality
 Monitoring.
 
 The Acton Wakefield Watersheds Alliance (AWWA) proposes to work with the Province Lake
 Association (PLA) and other local partners to implement recommended action items consistent with goals that will improve water quality within the Province Lake watershed. Previous projects have resulted in over 100 lbs. per year of phosphorus reduction, which is ~40% of our target load reduction goal for the watershed. This project will target substandard wastewater systems, stabilize areas experiencing shoreline erosion, install residential erosion control BMPs, and continue outreach and water quality monitoring programs. When completed, it is estimated the management activities implemented through this project will prevent 7 Â¿ 12 lbs. of phosphorus from reaching the lake annually.

column67: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF DEVELOPMENT ORGANIZATIONS RESEARCH FOUNDATION, INC. (THE)
column90:
Task 1: Support with Coordinating, Marketing, and Distributing Materials and Updates to NADO Membership and Other Partners 
 The NADO Research Foundation (NADO RF) will support the project team by promoting upcoming events and webinars, services, and other resources and distributing information and updates to the NADO membership and its partners. NADO RF is the research arm of the National Association of Development Organizations (NADO), a national membership association of regional development organizations (RDOs) that serve primarily smaller metropolitan and rural regions. These entities work to improve local and regional quality of life by promoting economic and community development through place-based strategies in the areas of housing, transportation, infrastructure, workforce development, entrepreneurship, disaster resilience, aging services, and other sectors. 
 NADO RF staff will carry out this task by sharing information and updates through its weekly newsletter NADO News (readership 1,500), the NADO website, social media channels, and eÂ mail blasts to the membership, as well as targeted outreach to members and their partners who may benefit from the services offered by the project team. 
 Task 2: Plan, Promote, and Deliver Two Webinars
 NADO RF staff will organize two webinars during the project that will feature how regional development organizations are supporting small water systems projects in their regions and highlight best practices and case studies. These webinars will follow a similar model to the webinars delivered in previous rounds, "RDOs: Supporting Water Infrastructure and Improving Quality of Life" (November 15, 2018), "Connecting the Dots: Regional Development Organizations and Water Systems" (May 16, 2019), and "Leveraging Regional Development Organizations to Support Small Water Systems" (January 26, 2021). 
 Task 3: Plan and Write Two Blog Posts 
 NADO RF staff will write two blog posts that will highlight case studies and best practices of how regional development organizations are partnering with local communities to support small water systems projects.
 Task 4: Participate on Project Team Conference Calls and Other Team-Building Events 
 NADO RF staff will participate on weekly planning calls with the project team, as well as other team-building activities. Staff will maintain consistent communication with project partners to develop and improve outreach, marketing, and event planning. 
 Task 5: Facilitate Opportunities for In-Person Events and Workshops 
 NADO RF staff will collaborate with the project team to identify and pursue opportunities for the project team to conduct in-person workshops and other trainings. These may include events at established NADO conferences such as the Annual Training Conference and other regional convenings, at other partner events, and/or on-site in RDO regions.

column55: This agreement provides funding to the State of Indiana Department of Environmental Management to carry out its program to maintain, protect, and improve the water quality of its rivers, lakes, streams, groundwater, and other waterbodies. The environmental benefits of this program include preventing degradation of unimpaired waterbodies and reducing the number of impaired waterbodies in the state. Activities include collecting fish tissue data from waters throughout the state of Indiana to support multiple water quality management objectives, purchase monitoring equipment to deploy at three regional monitoring network sites, and fund a contractor with the ability to combine several different data sets for Indiana lakes into a single master spreadsheet file to use in developing an attribute-rich, high-resolution Indiana Reach Index (a geospatial data layer at 1:24,000 scale) for lakes.

column90:
This project seeks $6,670 to fund Indiana Department of Environmental Management (IDEM), Office of Water Quality, Watershed Assessment and Planning Branch staff attendance at critical regional and national training meetings. Funds would be used to pay for necessary hotel and per diem expenses for three Watershed Assessment and Planning Branch staff to attend the annual U.S. EPA Region 5 Water Quality Monitoring Managerâ  s Meeting in Chicago, December 2021.  This meeting brings together state water quality monitoring program managers from the states of Minnesota, Wisconsin, Illinois, Indiana, Ohio, and Michigan so that programs can be discussed, experiences can be shared, and coordination can be conducted with Region 5 staff.  Estimated cost is $2,068.
 
 Funds would be used to pay for necessary registration, air travel, hotel, and per diem expenses for three Watershed Assessment and Planning Branch staff to attend the 12th National Monitoring Conference to be held in Providence, Rhode Island during the week of April 19, 2021.  This was a virtual conference and the cost was only $155/person for registration and 4 people attended for a total cost of $620.  Remaining funds will be used for future National Monitoring Conferences during the Grant period.  This is a biennial conference sponsored by the National Water Quality Monitoring Council, which is co-chaired at the national level by U.S. EPA and USGS.  At National Monitoring Conferences, anywhere from 600-900 attendees gather, representing local, state, and federal governmental entities; scientists; regulators; environmental organizations; wastewater and public water supply treatment managers; university researchers; volunteer organization leaders and citizen volunteers; monitoring equipment vendors; and others gather to discuss all-things-monitoring.  Technical staff will be provided the opportunity to attend and participate in this conference training experience for the benefit of the Branch, Office of Water Quality, and IDEM as a whole.  Estimated cost is $4,602.

column56: 66.454: WATER QUALITY MANAGEMENT PLANNING
column90: Robinson Pond is an 88-acre pond within an 1,100-acre watershed. Robinson Pond is home to the town swimming beach, boat launch, and picnic area. It is an important and popular natural resource for the residents of Hudson, NH. An extensive trail system and wildlife sanctuary exist adjacent to the pond. Despite the best efforts of the conservationists, active volunteer water quality monitors, and a citizens group working on behalf of the pondÂ¿s health, historic trend analysis indicates the pond is affected by consistently high and worsening levels of nutrient pollution which contributes to conditions that promote algal and cyanobacteria levels that exceed water quality thresholds. This plan will specifically address these issues in a holistic, watershed-level manner. Specifically, the plan will estimate pollutant loads from various sources, particularly phosphorus, and make recommendations on management actions to reduce loading, and lay out an action plan for success. Ultimately, the goal is to help reach the PondÂ¿s potential for restoration and sustained protection into the future.

column90: Solids Handling Improvement Project, the City of Bend's Water Reclamation Facility (WRF) solids handling dewatering process has maintenance, redundancy, and operational challenges. The system is nearing capacity and there is heavy corrosion in both the building and on the equipment resulting in deterioration of assets. The objective of the Solids Handling Improvement Project is upgrade the solids dewatering process to ensure (1) increase in dewatering performance while continuing to produce Class A biosolids, (2) increase capacity, (3) increase asset lifespan, and (4) provide a safe work environment for staff.

column90: This project will assess how past stormwater management may have affected freshwater quality and benthic index of biotic integrity (B-IBI) scores in King County streams. column55: This agreement provides funding to the University of New Orleans Research and Technology Foundation (UNORTF) to support the Lake Pontchartrain Basin Restoration program which maintains, protects and restores the water quality of the Lake Pontchartrain Basin. UNORTF will oversee projects to monitor the lake's water quality and determine the health of the watershed, develop green infrastructure municipal education, educate basin residents on water protection and pollution prevention, conduct sewer system evaluations and surveys, and develop designs and studies to determine infrastructure upgrades to prevent or reduce pollution.
column56: 66.125: LAKE PONTCHARTRAIN BASIN RESTORATION PROGRAM (PRP)
column81: U.S. Local Government,County,Local Government Owned,Council of Governments
column90: The Southshore of Lake Pontchartrain in Jefferson Parish includes the Hurricane Storm Damage Risk Reduction System (HSDRRS), which includes miles of levees that have walking and biking paths that are elevated atop the levee and meander down near to the waterfront. Jefferson Parish has developed a master plan for the Bucktown Harbor Park and will be implementing various projects to attract visitors to the site and needs to have coordinated educational elements for visitors to gain a greater appreciation for the unique coastal environment that surrounds our urban areas. In addition to Bucktown Harbor, Jefferson Parish is committed to connecting its residents to the water that surrounds them through projects that create a more diverse Lake Pontchartrain shoreline beyond the levees and floodwalls that protect Jefferson from hurricanes. The projects in this proposal will design and highlight these coastal features to connect and engage our citizens. In early 2020, during the COVID-19 pandemic, our area s interest in and appreciation for outdoor spaces has greatly increased; however, the Lakefront Trail does not have adequate rest stations or shaded spaces or outdoor educational spaces. The education spaces can be used by school groups, civic associations, parish meetings, and others as the growing demand shifts from indoor spaces to outside gathering locations. These coordinated and scalable projects will provide an opportunity to highlight different Best Management Practices (BMP)s for stormwater management methods that aid in the water quality of the lake and educate visitors about ways to improve the water quality.

column67: AGRICULTURE AND LAND STEWARDSHIP, IOWA DEPARTMENT OF
column90: Black Hawk Lake is a natural lake in Sac County, Iowa with a drainage area of 13,156 acres and is currently on the 303(d) impaired waters list for algae and turbidity.  The focus of the project is to work with partners including the City of Lake City and the Black Hawk Lake Protective Association, as well as residents, landowners and farm operators to reduce nutrient and sediment loss that is impairing Black Hawk Lake.  The watershed has a goal of addressing the excess sediment and phosphorus load that has been identified as the primary cause of water quality problems in the lake. TMDL findings indicate that a 78% reduction of phosphorus inputs is needed to achieve water quality success.  This sub-award will place an emphasis on load reductions from row crops, streambanks and urban inputs.

column55: This assistance agreement provides $1,730,862 of federal funding to promote and implement green infrastructure (GI) throughout the Bay Area to improve stormwater quality which can impact the health of San Francisco Bay. The project consists of  Planning, Implementation and Tracking tasks. In the planning phase, the project will: 1) upgrade and enhance the watershed-based GreenPlan-IT tool, 2) integrate GI into local planning efforts in various partnering jurisdictions, and 3) support a roundtable process to explore long term funding for implementing GI in the region. The implementation phase includes: 1) a design contest to develop cost-effective GI designs for typical roadway intersections, with construction of up to three GI projects based on the winning designs, and 2) construction of the Chynoweth Avenue Green Street Project in San Jose. column55: This cooperative agreement is provided to the University of Southern Maine, which is part of the University of Maine System, to support implementation of the Casco Bay Estuary Partnership's (CBEP) Comprehensive Conservation and Management Plan (CCMP). The goal is to restore and maintain the chemical, physical, and biological integrity of the estuary and support its sustainable human uses through tasks outlined in annual workplans of the CBEP and its partners.The cooperative agreement supports activities that will: 1) protect, restore, and enhance key habitats that sustain ecological health; 2) reduce nutrient pollution and its impacts, including coastal acidification; 3) foster resilient communities and their connections to Casco Bay, and; 4) mobilize collective knowledge and resources to support Casco Bay. Sub-awards will be provided to implement priority action plans in the CCMP. This is implementation year 25.

The Performance Partnership Agreement PPA serves as the definative workplan for the Performance Partnership Grant (PPG). column55: This funding is authorized by Section 120 of the Clean Water Act. This award will help the New England Interstate Water Pollution Control Commission's (NEIWPCC's) Lake Champlain Basin Program (LCBP) staff to accomplish the following goals:  1) coordinate the continued exchange of State, Federal and local perspectives and concerns on LCBP programs and activities; 2) advise the Steering Committee, States of Vermont and New York, and the Environmental Protection Agency of progress toward achieving objectives of LCBP's Work Plans and other activities; 3) reduce phosphorus inputs to Lake Champlain to promote a healthy and diverse ecosystem and provide for sustainable human use and enjoyment of the Lake; 4) reduce toxic contamination to protect public health and the Lake Champlain ecosystem; 5) promote a basin-wide perspective on water quality issues of regional and national importance; 6) coordinate efforts of water pollution control experts to assist in evaluating the spread of invasive sp

column90: Pickering Creek Audubon Center (Pickering Creek) will work with all 7th grade students (339), five 7th grade science teachers and the science supervisor at Talbot County Public Schools (TCPS) to connect them to issues and investigations around biodiversity through a new MWEE (Meaningful Watershed Educational Experience) program, Biodiversity Makes the Bay Better. The Educatorâ  s Guide to a MWEE and the MWEE audit tool will be used to inform and guide the collaborative process of implementing the MWEE with teachers and students. In partnership with TCPS staff, Pickering Creek will train and use Earth Forceâ  s Community Action and Problem-Solving Process model as a tool for increasing student investment in investigating Chesapeake Bay watershed health issues and to create a unit for students that poses a driving question about biodiversity, leading them through a process that concludes with a community-based action project. Through this project, students will connect with nature near their schools. This project will fulfill TCPSâ   environmental literacy planâ  s need to have a sustainable (yearly) middle school grade band MWEE as is suggested for all Maryland county curriculums, following state environmental literacy standards and environmental education community guidelines.

column55: This agreement will provide assistance to the Vermont Department of Environmental Conservation (VTDEC) in its efforts to reduce diesel emissions and exposure throughout the State of Vermont.  VTDEC will initiate work under this program with a series of open solicitations to local, state, and regional agencies or departments, as well as businesses operating primarily in Vermont. The program will prioritize fleets operating in high population areas, where sensitive populations are located, and in areas that receive a disproportionate quantity of air pollution from diesel fleets. Eligible diesel vehicles, engines, and equipment include verified emission control technologies such as exhaust controls, cleaner fuels, and engine upgrades, verified idle reduction technologies, verified aerodynamic technologies and low rolling resistance tires, certified engine replacements, and/or certified vehicle or equipment replacement. column55: This cooperative agreement will fund the New England Environmental Finance Center (EFC) as part of the national EFC program run by EPA. The Environmental Finance Centers provide multi-media environmental finance expertise and outreach to regulated communities (e.g., states, tribes, local governments, and private sector entities) to help them meet environmental requirements. The objective is to help the regulated parties in these communities find effective and innovative ways to help address the growing costs of protecting public health and the environment in a sustainable and equitable manner. Under this program, EFC'''s will be established and supported in EPA regions across the nation to provide regulated parties with finance-related training, technical assistance, finance studies, and other analytical support (eligible services) to help them develop sustainable solutions to the critical 'how-to-pay' issues associated with meeting environmental standards and goals. column90:
The US 231 Elevated Water Tank Project will address the lack of storage volume within the existing pressure zone. The new 500,000 gallon elevated tank will replace the existing Lambert Road ground storage tank to address the short fill cycles and the lack of adequate storage capacity in this portion of the ACWD distribution system. 200 LF of 12-inch DI pipe will make a connection to the existing 12-inch waterline along US 231. The existing Lambert Road storage tank will be removed from operation and ultimately be decommissioned. In addition to the new elevated tank approximately 9,000 LF of 8-inch PVC water line will be run along Bowling Green Road to transport water being pumped via the Halfway Booster Station to the Walkerâ  s Chapel Pressure Zone. The existing waterline along Bowling Green Road will be connected to the existing 12-inch waterline along US 231 via 1,000 LF of 8-inch waterline along Spears Road to place additional customers on the new tank. The Halfway Booster Station will have some internal piping switched out for installation of a new master meter to aid in ACWDâ  s Water Loss Program.
 
 Contract 03 â   Walnut Creek WLE (Residual Funds) will extend a new waterline parallel to Walnut Creek Road to serve existing customers and provide a new pressure supply to the Walnut Creek Road area to improve pressures that have been reduced due to changes in supply and during high demand usages. The new 8-inch waterline will be approximately 4,000 LF from the intersection of 31-E to Walnut Creek Road and Old Glasgow Road.

UNORTF will oversee projects to monitor the lake's water quality and determine the health of the watershed, develop green infrastructure municipal education, educate basin residents on water protection and pollution prevention, conduct sewer system evaluations and surveys, and develop designs and studies to determine infrastructure upgrades to prevent or reduce pollution.
column56: 66.125: LAKE PONTCHARTRAIN BASIN RESTORATION PROGRAM (PRP)
column90: The goal of the project is to complete an audit of the Parish's existing codes and ordinances pertaining to clearing & grubbing and sediment erosion control, and obtain recommendations for improving and consolidating the ordinances. The recommendations from this study can then be used by the Dept of Environmental Affairs to work with the Parish Administration to propose ordinance changes to the Council. Ultimately upon adoption, Jefferson Parish Environmental Affairs will have a better administrative process for controlling sediment pollution within its Jurisdiction in the Lake Pontchartrain Basin. A secondary benefit of this project is that clear and concise erosion and sediment control measures can be used for Community Rating System (CRS) credit. The CRS is a voluntary, incentive-based community program that recognizes, encourages, and rewards local floodplain management activities that exceed the minimum standards of the National Flood Insurance Program. Aside from floodplain management and hazard mitigation, one of the goals of CRS is protection of the environment provided by the credited activities.

column28: 0000: UNKNOWN;1202: WATER QUALITY RESEARCH ADN SUPPORT GRANTS
column31: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH CAROLINA AT CHAPEL HILL
column46: Public/State Controlled Institution of Higher Education
column55: The Environmental Finance Center Network, the Government Finance Officers Association, the National Association of Development Organizations, and the Rural Community Assistance Corporation will provide training and technical assistance to small drinking water systems in the areas of financial and managerial capacity. The team will help systems understand their expenses, develop sound revenue generation measures, improve energy and water efficiency, manage assets at the lowest life-cycle cost, communicate with decision makers and customers, and have appropriately trained staff to maintain compliance. Services will focus on either a single finance or management topic (e.g., asset management) or package several topics into a theme (e.g., natural disaster resilience).
column56: 66.424: SURVEYS, STUDIES, INVESTIGATIONS, DEMONSTRATIONS, AND TRAINING GRANTS - SECTION 1442 OF THE SAFE DRINKING WATER ACT

column90: The National Association of Development Organizations (NADO) will promote upcoming events and webinars, services and other resources, and distribute information and updates to the NADO membership and its partners who serve primarily smaller metropolitan and rural regions and work to improve local and regional quality of life by promoting economic and community development.

column55: This project aims to analyze and communicate the potential impacts of coastal flooding of contaminated sites on vulnerable communities. Researchers will derive area-level measures of biological susceptibility and social vulnerability to characterize the vulnerability of communities living near to sites with excess releases. Researchers will also develop accessible, bilingual online mapping and data visualization tools and in-person roundtables in three at-risk coastal communities on the East, West, and Gulf Coasts.
column56: 66.509: SCIENCE TO ACHIEVE RESULTS (STAR) RESEARCH PROGRAM
column90: This project will integrate data on 1) emission of hazardous materials from contaminated sites during Hurricane Harvey, 2) flood projections incorporating sea level rise, 3) the location and characteristics of contaminated sites across the U.S., and 4) measure of population vulnerability to environmental health hazards related to age, income, housing, education, race/ethnicity, linguistic isolation, and other factors in order to characterize and broadly communicate the environmental health risks and environmental justice implications of flooding of contaminated sites across the United States.

column55: The Environmental Finance Center Network, the Government Finance Officers Association, the National Association of Development Organizations, and the Rural Community Assistance Corporation will provide training and technical assistance to small drinking water systems in the areas of financial and managerial capacity. The team will help systems understand their expenses, develop sound revenue generation measures, improve energy and water efficiency, manage assets at the lowest life-cycle cost, communicate with decision makers and customers, and have appropriately trained staff to maintain compliance. Services will focus on either a single finance or management topic (e.g., asset management) or package several topics into a theme (e.g., natural disaster resilience).

column56: 66.460: NONPOINT SOURCE IMPLEMENTATION GRANTS
column90: This project will implement shoreline, gully, and streambank stabilization best management practices in the Cedar Lake/ Big Muddy River watershed to reduce nonpoint source pollution to protect water quality. BMP's will include shoreline stabilization done utilizing stone riprap applied by special application boats. Streambank stabilization will include a shaping existing banks and stabilizing with geotextile fabric and stone riprap. Toe protection and end transition will include trenching fabric and riprap into existing stable material.

column90:
Currently, the entire east side water network is served by a single 12-inch waterline suspended from the NM 6 bridge crossing the Rio Grande. If the 12-inch line breaks or needs to be shut down for maintenance, the entire east side of the Village will lose fire protection and
 water service. A second river crossing will eliminate this danger. The project will also seek to meet goals identified in the 2014 Los Lunas Water Master Plan. Available peak hour fire flows to the commercial area on the east side fall short of the flows recommended by the
 Master Plan. Because Phase 1 includes the Rio Grande crossing, it will provide the redundancy needed to prevent the loss of east side water service and fire protection if the existing 12-inch Rio Grande waterline crossing is shut down for any reason. Phase 1 will also double
 existing available peak hour fire flows.

column55: This amendment awards federal funds of $3,673,237 to fully fund this award and extends the budget and project periods to 9/30/2022. The purpose of this project is to reduce nutrient and sediment loads that cause or contribute to the impairment of water quality standards in the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries. Activities funded through this award will focus on enforcement and compliance assurance, nutrient management compliance assurance, and improved tracking and accountability. This work will help to achieve and maintain the water quality necessary to improve the aquatic system health of the Chesapeake Bay ecosystem. Beneficiaries of this project include residents of the Chesapeake Bay, human health, and the environment. The recipient plans to subaward funds to support data management and implementation of Pennsylvania's Chesapeake Bay Watershed Implementation Plan.

column90:
This project involves replacing existing plastic fittings with ductile iron, adding valves to allow isolation of lines for maintenance, adding/replacing fire hydrants, replacing all meters with new radio read meters, replacing all service tubing from the main to the meter, and creating a new monitoring system (SCADA) for the tank and master meter.
 
 Revised Scope: In addition to the work listed above, the system has received approval to install a new line extension along White City Rd and Tirey Ln to serve customers currently without drinking water service since the project was under budget. The new line extension will include approximately 1300 LF of 3' PVC waterline along White City Rd, 600 LF of 2" PVC waterline along Tirey Ln, and 4900 LF of 2" PVC waterline along White City Rd. The project will also include a flush hydrant, three new valves, 6 new AMR meters, and a steel cased road bore.

column28: 0000: UNKNOWN;0063: GEOGRAPHIC PROGRAM:  CHESAPEAKE BAY;3063: GEOGRAPHIC PROGRAM:  CHESAPEAKE BAY
column55: This amendment awards federal funds of $3,673,237 to fully fund this award and extends the budget and project periods to 9/30/2022. The purpose of this project is to reduce nutrient and sediment loads that cause or contribute to the impairment of water quality standards in the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries. Activities funded through this award will focus on enforcement and compliance assurance, nutrient management compliance assurance, and improved tracking and accountability. This work will help to achieve and maintain the water quality necessary to improve the aquatic system health of the Chesapeake Bay ecosystem. Beneficiaries of this project include residents of the Chesapeake Bay, human health, and the environment. The recipient plans to subaward funds to support data management and implementation of Pennsylvania's Chesapeake Bay Watershed Implementation Plan.
column56: 66.466: CHESAPEAKE BAY PROGRAM
column90: Delegation of Nutrient and Manure Management Program duties to County Conservation Districts under PA Act 38 and DEP Chapter 91 Regulations.

column56: 66.466: CHESAPEAKE BAY PROGRAM
column90: Washington As It Was: A Virtual Field Trip to Peirce Mill in Rock Creek Park

column55: This agreement will provide assistance to the Alamo Area Council in its efforts to reduce diesel emissions and exposure in the state of Texas, Bexar county, which was designated in 2018 as a marginal nonattainment area under the 2015 ozone National Ambient Air Quality Standards (NAAQS). This project consists of replacing two (2) diesel-powered 2012 model Capacity TJ 6500 terminal tractors with all-electric models, including the proper disposal of old vehicles and procurement of replacement vehicles. Also included in this project is the procurement and installation of associated charging infrastructure. This project will reduce emissions of diesel particulate matter and other pollutants such as nitrogen oxides and carbon monoxide.
column56: 66.039: NATIONAL CLEAN DIESEL EMISSIONS REDUCTION PROGRAM
column90: SUBRECIPIENT will purchase and operate two electric terminal tractors and associated charging infrastructure, including installation, and ensure the proper treatment of old equipment being replaced in accordance with EPA requirements.

column55: The project will provide funding for Plumas County to inventory, characterize, perform hazardous substance site assessments and cleanup planning for Crescent Mills, a former sawmill site. The old mill is being redeveloped into a wood utilization campus to offer significant economic development potential for Plumas County, spur forest restoration, and at full buildout, the campus will generate between 15-30 wood products industry jobs for a rural community in need of economic revitalization.  This agreement provides full federal funding in the amount of $200,000.  See terms and conditions.  Pre-award costs have been approved back to July 1, 2017
column56: 66.818: BROWNFIELDS ASSESSMENT AND CLEANUP COOPERATIVE AGREEMENTS

column56: 66.468: CAPITALIZATION GRANTS FOR DRINKING WATER STATE REVOLVING FUNDS
column81: U.S. Local Government,Municipality,City,Planning Commission,Council of Governments
column90:
The City of Orange City is experiencing water quality challenges with the Safe Drinking Water Act allowable limits for Disinfection by-Products and iron.  Two (2) projects were submitted for SRF to improve water quality for the entire system - total estimated costs for both projects is $19,405798. The following is a brief description for each project:
 Project 1 - Disinfection By-Product Reduction with a Greensand Filtration System. The Greensand Filtration System is necessary to remove high iron and total organic carbon (TOC) levels in a new constructed Well (#3R) and other two Wells on site.  TOC levels are higher than 2 mg/L, which will result on high disinfection by-products formation. Also, iron level is exceeding the SDWA Secondary regulatory limit (0.3 mg/L).
 Project 2 â   Pipe Rehabilitation and Looping Projects. This project will replace hydraulically dysfunctional water mains. These hydraulically defective water mains are still causing two sampling points TTTHMs excedances for the regulatory levels under Stage 2 DBPs Rule.  Galvanize, corroded ductile iron, and new water mains not connected to existing services are causing high water loss, high water age, and unwanted bottlenecks within the water distribution system.

The activities are to provide low interest financing to numerous subrecipients for costs associated with the planning, design, and construction of their eligible drinking water improvement projects and activities to protect human health. The expected outcomes are to establish and manage an effective comprehensive drinking water program and to maintain a self-sustaining revolving fund to provide safe drinking water and protect public health for citizens throughout the state of Florida. Florida Department of Environmental Protection will award sub-awards for technical assistance to small systems, source water protection programs, and for the development and implementation of their capacity development strategy.

column35: PRESIDENT AND FELLOWS OF HARVARD COLLEGE
column55: The center will investigate the sources, composition, trends, and effects of regional air pollutant mixtures across the US over a period spanning past and future years (2000- 2040), and will examine the influence of climate, socioeconomic factors, policy decisions, and control strategies on air pollution, human health and economic outcomes.
column56: 66.509: SCIENCE TO ACHIEVE RESULTS (STAR) PROGRAM; 66.509: SCIENCE TO ACHIEVE RESULTS (STAR) RESEARCH PROGRAM
column81: Private University or College,Non-Profit Organization,1862 Land Grant College,Educational Institution
column90:
Objectives: In Project 5, we will investigate future changes in regional air pollution
 characteristics as a result of technological and societal changes. We will quantify
 the future implications of technologies and efficiency improvements in the energy
 and transportation sectors on regional differences in air pollution impacts. As a
 case study, we will assess the environmental and health benefits of choices in
 state and regional carbon policy implementation relevant to recently proposed
 carbon dioxide emission reductions from the energy sector. We will examine the
 health related benefits of reducing concentrations of ozone and particulate matter,
 as well as changing regional air pollution mixtures including air toxics.Approach: We will use an integrated assessment model framework linking
 economic models with details on advanced technologies for transportation and
 energy supply that consistently simulations economic and population growth, air
 quality, and health impacts, including the economic implications of air pollution
 health impacts. We will use matrices developed using air pollution sensitivities to
 source and region-based emissions from the GEOS-Chem chemical transport
 model to create a computationally-efficient integrated framework, which we will use
 to conduct quantitative uncertainty analysis of modifiable and other factors and
 their influence on future regional-scale air quality and its health and economic
 impacts. We will analyze case of future technology scenarios for carbon reduction
 strategies in the energy and transportation sector using economic model
 simulations, and examine the influence of global change scenarios by driving our
 integrated assessment framework with future meteorology.
 Expected results: This project will result in a computationally-efficient analysis tool
 that can be used to assess the relative importance of global change, technologies,
 and policies to air quality, including their costs and benefits, and taking into
 account uncertainties. We will identify the factors and modifiable strategies with
 most influence on air pollution health impacts, quantifying associated uncertainty
 ranges. The approach allows for a consistent estimates of the costs and cobenefits of regional carbon reduction strategies in combination with other air
 pollution reduction initiatives, including controls on air toxics.
 Personnel: Prof. Noelle Selin will coordinate integrated assessment modeling at
 MIT. Her research group developed the MIT Integrated Economy-Air QualityHealth Assessment framework. Prof. Barrett will lead modeling work using the
 GEOS-Chem XPLEX (which was developed in his group) and adjoint applications
 to health assessment, working closely with other PIs as this modeling is integrated
 within the larger framework. Prof. Susan Solomon will contribute to air quality
 analysis, in particular focusing on identifying sensitivity of PM changes to
 emissions changes. Dr. John Reilly will contribute expertise on economics and
 coordinate work on USREP-Reeds. Dr. Erwan Monier, whose research focuses on
 climate change and its impacts, will contribute as a research scientist to efforts
 using the IGSM-CAM. A postdoctoral associate working with Profs. Selin and
 Solomon will conduct integrated assessment work. A postdoctoral associate cosupervised by Dr. Reilly and Prof. Selin will assist with economic modeling and
 analysis. A graduate student co-supervised by Profs. Selin, Barrett and Solomon
 will run GEOS-Chem.

column55: This agreement provides funding to the State of Texas to carry out its program to maintain, protect, and improve the water quality of its rivers, lakes, streams, groundwater, and other waterbodies. The environmental benefits of this program include preventing degradation of unimpaired waterbodies and reducing the number of impaired waterbodies in the state. Activities include supporting work for a comprehensive survey of the nation's wetlands. The National Wetlands Condition Assessment is a statistical survey of wetlands of the U.S. This survey is designed to: 1. Produce a national report that describes the status of water quality of nation's wetlands, 2. evaluate change in the status of the nation's wetlands since the initial phase in 2010, 3. help states implement wetland monitoring and assessment programs to guide policy development and project decision-making, and 4. advance the science of wetland monitoring and assessment.

column90:
Updating State Capacity Development Strategies for Asset Management Project August 2020 
 Budget Total: $112,000 
 Budget for Southwest EFC: $56,000 
 Timeframe: 15 months (Oct 2020-Dec 2021 [Dec. 2021 is statutory deadline for updated strategies]) 
 PTE EFC: 
 Wichita State University EFC, AI97756601 
 Subrecipient EFC: 
 Southwest EFC - University of New Mexico 
 Project Description: 
 The Southwest EFC will work with the Wichita State EFC to assist states in revising their capacity development strategies in order to incorporate asset management, which is mandated by America's Water Infrastructure Act (AWIA) of 2018. Specifically, the SW EFC will assist with the following: 
  Assisting in the identification of beneficial products that would assist states in updating their strategies. These products may include checklists, key questions, or other tools to inform state efforts.
  Participating in Workgroup for Creating Guidance Worksheet for Revising Capacity Development Strategies to Include Asset Management (The Workgroup). Review and revise the worksheet originally published as part of the Guidance on Implementing the Capacity Development Provisions of the Safe Drinking Water Act Amendments of 1996 as part of this Workgroup.
  Serving as a resource to assist states in updating their strategies, including sharing best practices among states and connecting peer states who are experiencing similar challenges.    Providing updates to EPA on key questions being asked by states and state support needs, including the need for additional tools or resources that may be helpful as states work toward their 2021 deadline for strategy updates.
  Increasing awareness among state capacity development programs of the resources EPA has developed to assist in their strategy-update efforts.

"The Letcher County Water District (â  LCWDâ  ) is requesting a Fund F loan in the amount of $4,000,000 for the Letcher County WTP project. This project will construct a 1,000,000 GPD water treatment plant at the Letcher and Perry County line on Highway 7.  The project will include construction of the plant, the intake with 387 LF of 8"" DI to the intake and approximately 295 LF of 8"" DI to tie into the existing LCWSD system. The plant will be owned and operated by the LCWSD.
 
 The WTP will include VFD raw water and high service pumps, LED lighting (interior/exterior), Energy Star rate appliances/fixtures, stand-by diesel generators, Low E windows, Reflective Membrane Roof, Raw water intake and screen with permanganate feed and forced air backwash, Chemical feed, Flocculation basins, Settling Basins, Filtration Basins, Finish water chemical feed, Clear well, Side storage, Sedimentation / backwash basin, Sludge Drying bed/and or sludge hopper, and Primary Disinfectant will be chlorine liquid.
 
 Currently the Letcher County Water District serves 2,989 residential and 10 commercial customers."

column90:
"The Letcher County Water and Sewer District is requesting a Fund F loan in the amount of $2,487,495 for the Regional Interconnect & Distribution Lines Cumberland River Phase 4 project. The proposed project will provide a first time source of potable water for approximately 200 households in Letcher County through the establishment of a regional interconnect with the City of Cumberland and the construction of distribution lines along the KY HWY 119 corridor in Letcher County. Residents of Collier's Creek and Lewis Branch will be served as part of this project. The project will also lay the foundation from which distribution can be expanded through the remainder of the Cumberland River area in subsequent Phases I, II and III. The project will be installed primarily on state and county rights of way and will utilize trenchless technology to accomplish any and all stream crossings. 
 
 The distribution lines portion of the project has been reviewed and approved by KYDOW.   Construction will include 13,753 LF of 6"" PVC, 10,385 LF of 4"" PVC, and 16,157 LF of 3"" PVC for a total of 40,295 LF of new waterline extension.  The project will also construct a 100,000-gallon storage tank, a 250 GPM Pump Station, six flushing hydrants, six blow off valves, sixteen 6"" Gate Valve, six 4"" Gate Valves, four 3"" Gate Valves, three air release valves, one pressure Stabilizing valve, and a master meter.  The project does include telemetry.
 
 Currently Letcher County Water and Sewer serves 2,989 residential and 10 commercial customers."

FGUA Acquisition of Flagler County Utilities - Project Summary
 This document provides an overview of the background and circumstances which have led to a proposal by the Florida
 Governmental Utility Authority (FGUA) and Flagler County (the â  Countyâ  ) to pursue a transfer of the County water and
 wastewater utility system consisting of the Plantation Bay, Beverly Beach, and Eagle Lakes subsystems (collectively, the
 â  Flagler Utility Systemâ   or â  Utility Systemâ  ) to the FGUA.
 The Flagler Utility System is facing difficult issues associated with aging infrastructure, regulatory violations, mounting
 debt, and potentially significant rate increases for utility customers. The FGUA, in cooperation with the County, has
 outlined a plan to transfer the systems, achieve regulatory compliance, complete needed capital improvements, and
 significantly reduce rate impacts on customers. The Utility System has also been struggling with operational challenges,
 such as marginal water quality and lack of experienced utility staff. Implementation of daily operational improvements
 and system stability has already begun with the FGUA assuming management and operational responsibilities on behalf
 of the County in February 2020.
 The outlined FGUA plan includes:
 a) the use of existing utility cash balances to complete a series of critical capital improvements to both the water and
 wastewater systems, as well as to fund various costs associated with the transaction; and
 b) the use of new SRF loan proceeds to support the retirement of the existing County utility debt of $16,365,356, and
 therefore facilitate the transfer of the Utility System to the FGUA.
 The referenced capital improvements will address much of the aging infrastructure and regulatory violations, and the
 proposed SRF loans will provide critical improvements to cash flow by replacing the higher interest rate debt currently
 held by the County. The improved system cash flow will help alleviate the need for the large rate increases on the utility
 customers that would have been necessary under the Countyâ  s previous plan.
 In summary, the SRF loans are a necessary element to implement the plan to transfer the Flagler Utility System to the
 FGUA. The benefits of implementing the plan to transfer the system to the FGUA include:
 â ¢ Ownership by a public entity with a singular focus on water and wastewater utilities.
 â ¢ Seasoned utility management and operational expertise.
 â ¢ Proven capabilities to carry out needed capital improvements.
 â ¢ New capital plan will significantly improve aging infrastructure.
 â ¢ Regulatory violations to be cured by new capital plan.
 â ¢ New capital plan will also address capital needs not previously contemplated.
 â ¢ Significant reduction in financial stress on the utility and reduced rate pressure on the customers.

column90:
Currently, the entire east side water network is served by a single 12-inch waterline suspended from the NM 6 bridge crossing the Rio Grande. If the 12-inch line breaks or needs to be shut down for maintenance, the entire east side of the Village will lose fire protection and
 water service. A second river crossing will eliminate this danger. The project will also seek to meet goals identified in the 2014 Los Lunas Water Master Plan. Available peak hour fire flows to the commercial area on the east side fall short of the flows recommended by the
 Master Plan. Because Phase 1 includes the Rio Grande crossing, it will provide the redundancy needed to prevent the loss of east side water service and fire protection if the existing 12-inch Rio Grande waterline crossing is shut down for any reason. Phase 1 will also double
 existing available peak hour fire flows.

column55: This action awards federal funds of $2,105,540, of which $489,540 is supplemental funding to support work in Delaware's most effective basins. Federal funds of $6,464,000 are contingent upon availability. This award supports Delaware in meeting its nutrient and sediment allocations, with the overall goal of achieving the restoration and protection of the Chesapeake Bay watershed and its living resources. This will be accomplished by implementing Delaware's Watershed Implementation Plans (WIPs) that detail a mix of best management practices (BMPs), wastewater treatment technology upgrades, and other activities necessary to restore and protect the Chesapeake Bay. Beneficiaries of this project include residents of the Chesapeake Bay watershed, human health, and environment. The recipient intends to subaward funds to support local implementation of best management practices aimed at improving water quality.

column28: 0000: UNKNOWN;00H4: DIESEL EMISSIONS REDUCTION GRANT PROGRAM
column31: ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICES, NEW HAMPSHIRE DEPARTMENT OF
column55: This agreement will provide assistance to the New Hampshire Department of Environmental Services in its efforts to reduce diesel emissions and exposure throughout the State of New Hampshire. NHDES will initiate a sub-grant program applied broadly across various sectors in the state, employing a variety of diesel reduction strategies. Eligible diesel vehicles, engines, and equipment include verified emission control technologies such as exhaust controls, cleaner fuels, and engine upgrades, verified idle reduction technologies, verified aerodynamic technologies and low rolling resistance tires, certified engine replacements, and/or certified vehicle or equipment replacement. All projects will reduce emissions of diesel particulate matter and other pollutants such as nitrogen oxides, carbon monoxide, and hydrocarbons.
column56: 66.040: DIESEL EMISSIONS REDUCTION ACT (DERA) STATE GRANTS; 66.040: STATE CLEAN DIESEL GRANT PROGRAM
column90:
Under the Diesel Emission Reduction Act (DERA) the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) provides funding to states for projects that reduce harmful emissions produced by older diesel engines, including replacement of vehicles with older diesel engines.  The new engines must meet more stringent emissions standards. Utilizing federal EPA funds, matched with funding from New Hampshireâ  s Volkswagen Environmental Mitigation Trust Fund, NHDES has approximately $500,000 available for grants under this Request for Proposals.  
 
 A request for proposals was conducted from February 8 through March 8, 2021.  Seven entities applied for funding (see Attachment A for the scoring results). Eversource Energy requested partial funding to replace eight (8) 2009 model year International Navistar 4400 SBA trucks. (See Attachment B for a list of vehicles)
 
 Eversource Energyâ  s existing bucket trucks operate an average of 12,369 miles per year, however they idle 6-8 hours per day to power the aerials, increasing the emissions in highly-populated and economically disadvantaged communities.  Additionally, these vehicles have an average existing mileage of about 152,000 miles with the highest mileage truck having almost 184,000 miles.  This project will replace the vehicles with diesel bucket trucks equipped with battery-powered aerials that will eliminate the majority of the idling time.
 
 The DERA program has a mandatory minimum cost share requirement for a vehicle replacement project of 25 percent. NHDES will provide a grant of $387,190 or 25 percent, whichever is less, of the total replacement cost (estimated at $2,326,939) to Eversource Energy for the replacement of eight (8) utility trucks.     
 
 This agreement has been approved as to form, substance, and execution by the Office of the Attorney General.  In the event that Federal funds become no longer available General funds will not be requested to support this program.

column56: 66.468: CAPITALIZATION GRANTS FOR DRINKING WATER STATE REVOLVING FUNDS
column90:
Currently, the entire east side water network is served by a single 12-inch waterline suspended from the NM 6 bridge crossing the Rio Grande. If the 12-inch line breaks or needs to be shut down for maintenance, the entire east side of the Village will lose fire protection and
 water service. A second river crossing will eliminate this danger. The project will also seek to meet goals identified in the 2014 Los Lunas Water Master Plan. Available peak hour fire flows to the commercial area on the east side fall short of the flows recommended by the
 Master Plan. Because Phase 1 includes the Rio Grande crossing, it will provide the redundancy needed to prevent the loss of east side water service and fire protection if the existing 12-inch Rio Grande waterline crossing is shut down for any reason. Phase 1 will also double
 existing available peak hour fire flows.

column55: This agreement provides funding to the State of Oklahoma to carry out its program to maintain, protect, and improve the water quality of its rivers, lakes, streams, groundwater, and other waterbodies. The environmental benefits of this program include preventing degradation of unimpaired waterbodies and reducing the number of impaired waterbodies in the state. Activities include issuing and enforcing National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) permits, conducting ambient monitoring of surface water and groundwater, and developing water quality management plans and Total Maximum Daily Loads (TMDLs).

column67: ALLIANCE FOR THE CHESAPEAKE BAY, INC
column71: ALLIANCE FOR THE CHESAPEAKE BAY, INC., THE
column90:
This project will build off of multiple previous CBIG investments by deepening the Alliance for the Chesapeake Bay's (the Alliance) engagement with Bowie State University, established through prior years' Chesapeake Watershed Forum (the
 Forum), and extend mutually beneficial learning experiences throughout the year. As in prior years, the Alliance will introduce up to 20 Bowie State students and their faculty advisors to the conservation and environmental restoration learning
 modules at the Alliance's 2020 Forum. This year it will also assist Dr. Alan
 Anderson at Bowie State in establishing a student-led water quality-monitoring project in order to connect their classroom studies to real-world application and watershed health. In spring 2021, the Alliance will develop (in coordination with
 Dr. Anderson and students) a two-part seminar series with programming that aims to increase knowledge on clean water and/or Bay-related natural resource topics. The majority of the funding from this CBIG project will be used for Alliance staff time to develop the monitoring program and train volunteers as well as to plan and execute the seminar series. The remaining funds will be used to ensure the students and faculty may register for the Forum, to cover travel for Alliance staff as related to the water quality-monitoring project and the seminars, and related costs tied to
 hosting the seminar series (facility rental, printing materials, etc.).
